reviews.review_title: A classic that still remains creepy to this day
reviews.content: I was probably around 8 or 9 when I saw Jaws, which would have being perhaps 2002/2003. Of course, I both enjoyed it and was creeped out by it. Spielberg has used excellent techniques in filming and writing. The three main actors are really good, the highlight probably being Robert Shaw for his portrayal of Quint, the grizzly, shark hunting war veteran who is able to persuade us and hook us (excuse my pun-after all, he is a fisherman!), and I especially enjoyed his U.S.S Indianapolis monologue. Roy Schneider and Richard Dreyfuss, along with Lorraine Gary and Murray Hamilton, also captivate the viewers. Scenes such as the attack on Chrissie Watkins or the scene in which the head pops out of the ruined boat are amongst the scary and thrilling scenes Jaws has to offer, and lines such as "I think we need a bigger boat" ave gone down as iconic lines in film history, along with such quotes as "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse" or "Here's Johnny! I sincerely hope rumors about a remake are false. Such an idea would ruin Jaws timeless legacy, as it's dismal sequels Jaws 3-D or Jaws the revenge did (Jaws 2 wasn't so bad) So if there are any filmmakers considering to redo Jaws that stumble upon this comment, please, for the sake of this film, don't!

steven Spielberg is great director and i'm big fan of him this is the greatest movie ever not because it is the best because with no doubt the most affected movie of all time it doesn't matter where you are from and what is your language when you think about shark first thing come in your mind is the jaws movie the suspense in this movie is great and the horror too and this movie proved if you have the talent you can do huge thing by less potentials

Simply amazing. One of the best feats of cinema. From the spine chilling music, to the jumps and scares delivered by sound design and editing. Super job!Robert Shaw's monologue is simply brilliant with not many being able to live up to his performance these days. Roy Scheider wad always a hero thanks to his portrayal of Brody, Dreyfus was his perfect counterpart.

reviews.review_title: What can you say, Spielberg is a GOD
reviews.content: I saw JAWS when it first came out, in 1975 and my parents had taken us to the drive-in.  From the short opening credits and John Williams pulsing score, I was hooked.  Steven Spielberg is The Master. Since that time I've seen the film more times than I can count, and I know it intimately.  Its been a childhood friend and undeniably one of the best adventure/horror films ever made.  The casting of the three primary roles could not have been better, can you see anyone besides Scheider, Dreyfuss or Shaw in the lead roles, I think not.If you haven't seen it rush out right now and get a copy... Widescreen of course (anything less IS just that)  Shot in 70mm the film still stands up against any film Hollywood can put out.Ignore the sequels stick to the one, the only,... The Classic.

The second time I've watched this i seriously had doubts in Steven Stielbergs skills as a director, but then again it was made in 1975. This music was unbearably boring to sit through. Directors must realise that blood and gore in a film isn't what makes this type of film good. in 1975 m y opinion will have been a lot different, but its 2006 now and it bores me to watch this film. The only part of this film that was at the least mildy frightening was not frightening at all, it gave you a shock. Nothing more. People who love this film have the right to their opinions, but in my opinion this is one of the worst of Spielberg. Go watch War of the worlds or Close Encounter of The Third Kind. These are the true greatest Spielberg films.

reviews.review_title: Greatest thing, let alone movie ever!
reviews.content: This one has it all, Suspense, horror, even subtle humor, don't be fooled by it's position in the top 250, it just isn't given the credit it should be, enjoy it over and over again.  Matures like a fine wine, but the sequels may leave a sour after taste, so stick to drinking from the original cup.

I first saw this film when I was ten years old (my parents would'nt let me watch it before that). I was terrified!! I got so freaked out that for about three years, I refused to go swimming in the ocean. I lived in Santa Cruz, California at the time. But what also happened was I became curious about sharks and started to study them. Strange, yes...but it helped cure my fear. However, even now I will NEVER get into a shark cage and be face to face with a Great White. I would die of sheer terror. Back to the movie.....Beyond the scare factor, this is a brilliant film. Well acted, well plotted. Solid all around. Steven Spielberg is a genius!!

Yoooo - thanks for this SS . I lived this movie. Luring in the grey white wid dah young chum buckets and the fishes n stuff. Classic bait & switch af. Dude these a jet and researches have to be careful interacting with predators in the deep sea (that flick wid LL Cool J was also tremendous via Dupe Blue Sea). I'm definitely a shark and fin fanatic I love all things aqua af line the Miami Dolphins mascot. It's to live for. Great film I can imagine being the fly in the wall when the writers abd producers were like "we want to build something captivating af - something that will take watchers and viewers on an emotional rollercoaster). Love , love, love it!!!

I forgot just how damn good this film is. An absolute masterclass in tension building which kept me on the edge of my seat, the same way it did the very first time I saw it.It's been said many times but it really is true. The films biggest weakness is its biggest strength. From not being able to properly see the shark, it allows this chaotic mystery to build up to the finale, keeping this very real feeling of danger because the viewer is equally as clueless to the scope of the beast as the characters in the film.A film that has well and truly stood the ages, an obvious must see for anyone even remotely interested in film.

Chief of Police on Amity Island, Martin Brody (played by Roy Scheider) is presented with a monumental problem one summer on the relatively peaceful island of Amity in the form of a huge, man-eating, great white shark feeding in the offshore waters. He is first alerted to the problem when the decomposing body of Christine 'Chrissy' Watkins (played by Susan Backlinie) washes up on shore and is found and reported. At first, the Mayor, Larry Vaughn (played by Murray Hamilton) gets the medical examiner to attribute her death to a simple boating accident, but, with the arrival of shark expert Matt Hooper, this verdict is questioned. Hooper contends that the cause of death could only be a large,hungry, predatorial shark. Larry, however ignores his expertise and continues to let the beaches be open. It is only with a second death,that of Alex M. Kintner (played by Jeffery Voorhees) that the townspeople are called to a meeting wherein the people continue to shortsightedly agree with Larry and call for the beaches to remain open. When the Fourth of July finally comes, business is booming and the beaches are packed, partially due to the fact that no one will go into the water. Then, after the urging of Larry, two of his friends, an old couple, venture into the water. They break the ice and cause others to join, but this only ends in disaster where another man is killed. After this final offense, the townspeople commission Quint (played by Robert Shaw), a shark hunter, to find and kill the shark for $10,000. Chief Brody and Hooper join him on this expedition upon his vessel, the Orca. They then play a suspenseful game of cat and mouse with the shark where it becomes unclear exactly who is hunting who for a while. But finally, after Quint is messily devoured, Brody kills the shark and Hooper and him swim safely back to shore. This movie was Spielberg's seventeenth, it ranks 91st on the list of the top 250 films of all time according to the International Movie Database and is one of the highest grossing films of all time. I completely agree with'lurker_from_persia's' take on the film, "...I seriously do recommend you seeing this if you haven't, and if you have, watch it again " When this film came out, it shocked audiences as one of the most graphic movies to come out yet and sent many moviegoers to the lobby or the bathroom in order to avoid throwing up. (Which seems unbelievable by today's standards.) But, it was light-years ahead of many of the movies filled with senseless nauseating gore that come out today. Because, in contrast to them, the plot of Jaws is both engrossing and suspenseful.Both of these characteristics are amplified by the unforgettable musical score. From the start, you feel vulnerable, since the first attack victimizes a naked woman, her nakedness makes her even more vulnerable and makes you question your own safety. Chief Brody is my favorite character from this movie, but I think that he would be incomplete without the wit of Hooper to accompany him. Both of them have many engrossing scenes such as the one where Hooper first arrives and attempts to help Chief Brody organize the 'shark hunters.' "You know the eight guys on the fantail launch out there? Well none of them are gonna get out of the harbor alive." Hooper to Brody Aside from comic relief, Hooper is also by far the most intelligent character in the story. He is called to Amity to convince Mayor Larry of the danger of the situation with the shark, but is met, at every turn, with the single-minded uncooperative spirit that Mayor Larry strives to keep. "What we are dealing with is a perfect engine, an eating machine. It's really a miracle of evolution. All this machine does is swim and eat and make little sharks, and that's all. Now, why don't you take a long look at this sign. Those proportions are correct. Hooper to Mayor Larry"Love to prove that, wouldn't ya? Get your name into the National Geographic." Larry's response to Hooper"You are going to ignore this particular problem until it swims up and bites you in the ass" Hooper to LarrySpielberg exploits people's 'hot spots' of fear in this movie and shows how ignorance can be bliss in the case of deadly creatures. "Martin, it's all psychological. You yell barracuda, everybody says, "Huh? What?" You yell shark we've got a panic on our hands on the Fourth of July" Larry to Chief BrodySpielberg also shows how excitable people are in panicked situations. In the scene following one of the shark attacks, where the eldest Brody son is playing on his boat, Chief Brody's wife changes from encouraging her son to play in the boat he got for his birthday to yelling at him to get out of it when she sees a picture of a shark eating a boat. He uses his directing genius to profile different types of personalities and their reactions to stressful situations. He shows Quint, the psychotic, run-and-gun, personality taking it all in stride versus Chief Brody, the responsible parent being noticeably worried and fighting for the safety of his family. When Spielberg directed Jaws, he made a blockbuster, a classic, and revolutionary movie. The first Jaws deserves all the credit it has gained, but the later sequels also deserve the more negative credit that they have gained. Spielberg created a monster in Jaws, one that has stood the test of time much like The Mummy or other classic creeps and one that continues to scare children before their summer trip to Florida.
+ Music + The atmosphere of the 70s + an interesting figure of Quint + The movie evokes emotions (mainly fear) + The shark is realistic +

reviews.review_title: The First and Best Summer Block Buster
reviews.content: What can I say that hasn't already been said a thousand times. (*WARNING UPCOMING SPOILERS) The plot is engaging and just all out excellent. The death scenes especaly Quint's were grusome (at least they were at the time, it's no Nightmare/Halloween 2/Jason gore fest). The acting is superb, Roy scheider, Robert Shaw, and Richard Dreyfuss should have all won gold, Dreyfuss for supporting and Scheider And Shaw as a tie for best. The later is unlikely I know but hey that's my opinion. There are some who even think (i.e. Me and My Father) that Dreyfuss won for Goodbye Girl (in which he also delivers a great performance) because the Academy felt they should have given it to him for Jaws. You especaly won't want to miss the Orca scene(s), perhaps the greatest in movie history. To get the full impact, if you can watch it on a big screen at the beach, close to the fourth of July is even better.

Most people don't realise that "Jaws" the whale is actually the hero of this movie, harmlessly going about his business eating fish and planktons like they do.Okay, and a dog. And a few people.The police cop stars interfering with things, firstly by getting a man with a beard and glasses to come and scare everybody with stories of being eaten. The fool even encourages local fishermen to murder the wrong whale, and afterwards cuts its belly open, when all it has eaten is a car.Then another man with a beard and a hat comes along and annoys everybody by scratching a blackboard. He takes the other two men out on his boat and, to his credit, gives the whale (Jaws) something to eat - himself!The police cop however makes a total mess of things and tries to feed the whale with a boat, then a compressed air cylinder. To make things worse he then tries to shoot the whale and can't even get that right, and shoots the cylinder by mistake. This blows the whale's head off. WHO'S THE KILLER NOW, EH?The best bit is when the zombie comes out of the hole underneath the boat and scares the frogmen off.

Thoroughly enjoyed the second half of this movie. The first half obviously sets up everything we need to know for the plot, the second half is incredibly tense and had me on the edge of my seat.Nothing overwhelmingly amazing, but really really excellent film making.

*Spoilers will indeed follow*What a load of crap, right.  A shark starts eating the locals of an island community, putting a sheriff, who happens to be afraid of water, on the spot.  The selfish mayor opposes the sheriff in shutting down the beaches because its bad for business, and puts some tourists out for lunch. Sheriff gets mad when son almost gets chomped so he enlists the aid of a cocky oceanologist and a crazed fisherman to kill the shark.  These three go out in a rickety old fishing boat to do battle, become amazed at shark's enormous size and swimming skills, and proceed to get their rickety old fishing boat smashed up by the gilled beast.  Cocky and stupid oceanologist goes down in a shark-proof cage, and narrowly escapes with his life.  The shark, apparently feeling confident, jumps on to the back of the boat and eats the fisherman.  Sheriff then manages to blow up the shark into millions of pieces before swimming gleefully back to shore with oceanologist.Yikes!  That sounds terrible, does it not.  But what is pretty unbelievable is that I just finished decribing to you the greatest film ever made.  Now let me explain why.Jaws was the breakthrough film by a then unrealized film director named Steven Spielberg.  Very young, very talented, and still possibly naive about the film industry, he undertook the overly ambitious and utterly preposterous task of bringing this story to the big screen.  At his disposal:  the prestigious lineage of Zanuck filmmakers (lots of money), a talented cast (none of them A-list), a devoted crew (very good swimmers), and a mechanical shark.  Luckily for him that shark never worked.The shark in the film becomes an unseen evil because, due to the technical difficulties involved, Spielberg and friends were not able to show it as much as they wanted.  This makes the film less of a gimicky B-list monster movie and more of a taut suspense-horror-adventure film.  Not seeing the shark makes the viewer more uneased, not being able to know where it is and what it is going to do next.  I mean if you were swimming in the ocean, how many of you would see the shark coming anyways.  All we know is that when that thumping music starts playing, the shark is there, and its going to try to eat someone.  Actually, they should have gave a cast credit at the end with shark played by John Williams, because his simple but very effective score steals the movie from any actor or mechanical shark that appears.

reviews.review_title: A very popular film which is slightly overrated in my opinion
reviews.content: Perhaps I am showing my age because I found it a chore to sit through Jaws every time I tried to watch it. Jaws was the first blockbuster and it is indeed a rousing sea adventure but the way it goes about it seemed rather pedestrian to me. The shot selection and camerawork is great- which is a given fact as this is Steven Spielberg we speak of. The acting is great throughout and the trio of Chief Brady, Hooper and Quint have become a fixation of cinema pop culture over the years, primarily because their banter and experience aboard the Orca is what most people remember. And of course the Shark itself which is probably even more scarier than movie monsters because they actually exist.

Simply put the greatest adventure movie of all-time. It is not even a debate! Still stands up against multi million dollar movies 40 odd years on. A timeless class. If you've never seen it, watch it ASAP!!!

The first Jaws film is by far the best film in the history of Spielberg or any other shark film. The music, script and story is just incredible, and in my opinion this film has presented the best quotes of film history, giving credit to Spielberg, Quint, Hooper and Brody, Jaws is the best film ever made

reviews.review_title: Good job Speilberg had no money then !
reviews.content:
If Speilberg made Jaws nowadays, when he can afford to make a movie to the cost of a small country's entire yearly budget, then the cinema would have been robbed of one of its finest moments.The main difference is that I am sure you would have seen the shark much more and that, of course, is a bad thing. The thing that scares the most is not the sight of something horrible or frightening but merely the thought. People who prefer books to films often say that books require much more imagination. Well what else is at work in the early scenes of Jaws, where you don't see the shark at all, but your imagination. Arguably the most chilling scene is the opening one when the girl gets savagely ripped apart. The only indication of a shark is the fact that nothing else could throw around a person like that but a great white.The weakest scenes, in my opinion, are near the end when the shark actively attacks the boat and we see far too much of what is a pretty average model. If Speilberg had the backing and money he had now he would have made an entirely different film and I would say an inferior one to this classic.Much of the plot and story comes from the fact that the shark cannot be seen and is being hunted down. How many great scenes would have been lost if it became a gore fest or an action adventure like so many of today's pathetic offerings ?Maybe I am not giving Speilberg enough credit. He is a great film maker and would have seen the benefit of suspense to his movie rather than outright graphic horror. It is the idea that a shark that big could be out there that put many people off swimming in the sea for a long time.
As we saw in the sequels even the same formula, handled in the wrong way, didn't work. Forget the sequels, Jaws is probably the best true thriller ever made made by one of the top directors and starring a perfect cast. And remember a shark the size of a bus could be out there somewhere, we don't belong in the sea !

reviews.review_title: Steven Spielberg could not have made this movie today
reviews.content: The million dollar golden boy of film couldn't and wouldn't make a film like Jaws again today.   The film was plagued with numerous problems, primarily having to do with a mechanical shark that worked as well as........ well, Spielberg's 1941.   These problems meant that Spielberg couldn't rely on ILM to create shocks, he had to create menace out of the old reliable horror tricks of suspenseful soundtrack, horrors unseen, and unique editing.   The result is a film that holds up far better than most of his films today. It's the only one, except perhaps Schindler's List that deserves the critical accolades thrown at it.   A great movie.  The only problem is that most transfers to video are absolutely dreadful.

Jaws is the first film I ever saw and to this day it scares me.  It is to put it quite simple masterful.  From the unforgettable opening scene to the explosive finale, this film had me riveted.  After the opening scene Spielberg allows a slow but suspenseful build up to the point where we actually get our first look at the shark.  Of course Roy, Robert and Richard all perform exceptionally well too.  One of the best acting moments in the film is definately Quint describing being torpedoed on The U.S.S Indinapolis.  The shark itself looks pretty realistic especially when you compare it with the dreadful Jaws The Revenge which was made over ten years later.

reviews.review_title: Worst dialogue in a movie ever
reviews.content: The dialogue is inaudible and it's so dumb. Too many fishing scenes on that damn boat. Did not need to be two hours and 10 mins this movie could have been two scenes. Person gets killed in water, they close the beach, roll credits. Waste of time.

As a scary movie, this movie fulfills. It did such a great job that, on many vacations to Mexico and Hawaii, as well as to Australia, New Zealand, the Cook Islands, etc., I didn't go in water past my knees. Ever. And I'm not alone in knowing it traumatized an entire generation of potential swimmers, divers, et al.I thought I'd challenge myself this summer and face the fear head on. I took an open water dive course (where I didn't think of sharks once underwater, knowing that my 'buddy' was more of a danger) -- and then watched 'Sharkwater'.If you're terrified of sharks because of 'Jaws', I implore you to watch 'Sharkwater'. Our Stephen Spielberg did a hell of a job in scaring the crap out of people, and I'll give him that. But the world' s shark population has decreased by an insane amount in the last 10 years because people don't care about these animals -- not pandas, not elephants, not cuddly -- but millions killed for fins, and trust me, peeps, sharks are incredibly important to the planetary ecosystem.'Jaws' did a great job in terrifying people, but it's not real, and it's not the truth.

This movie should be called "Shaw's" because Robert Shaw owns it. Roy Scheider and Richard Dreyfuss are competent, but Robert Shaw's performance as Quint is superb.As other reviewers have noted, "Jaws" isn't really scary, but it IS exciting (especially the second half). I would call it an adventure movie rather than a horror film. As other reviewers have also mentioned, apart from the the now-famous "approaching shark" motif, the John Williams score is insipid and sometimes seems utterly unsuited to the action on screen.If you've never seen it, see it if only for Shaw's bravura performance.

reviews.review_title: Feel Good Factor Like No Other!
reviews.content:
For me the obsession started in 1975 when I was carted off to see Jaws at the now demolished Plaza cinema in Cardiff.  I was 5 years old, I remember being there and being amazed though I was probably too young to be scared by it. Surely they wouldn't let 5 year olds see it today! This was the film that got me addicted to cinema, not Disney classics that most kids seem to love.Years later I remember watching Jaws on TV and being absolutely fascinated by it again but it was not until I bought a copy on VHS in about 1988 that I really started to watch the film in detail.  What a piece of work!  The second half of the film must be the best three-hander in film history, the casting of Shaw, Dreyfuss and Scheider has amazing chemistry.  Scheider's everyman, Martin Brody being the "fish out of water" against the salty Quint and Ocean Brat, Hooper's needling relationship. (Has anyone else noticed Scheider's resemblance to the shark?? - sorry Roy) Virtually every line that comes out of Quint's head is macho rhetoric that we'd all love to be able to quote verbatim when we are drunk.  He is from the same mould as Lt. Col. Bill Kilgore in Apocalypse Now.  A macho hard man impenetrable mostly but with a slightly soft centre when put under the microscope.Jaws has had an undeniable influence on our culture.  It has instilled in a generation a fear of what is under the water.  How many times have you had a moment of illogical panic whilst swimming?  For me and many I know this was put there by Jaws.  The "scars" scene is undeniably a Cinema classic and has been parodied and tributed many times. It is in this scene that we see a more human side to Quint emerging.  How many times have you heard people in desperate situations say "We're gonna need a bigger boat"? Just watch Buffy!
So much has been said about the film and it IS a flawed masterpiece but no one questions the fact Halliwell's rates this as two star film!  I love Halliwell's and this is the only real faux pas it contains.  Such a seminal film (the true father of summer blockbusters) and a film so well crafted, scored, acted and scripted should qualify as a four star. Technically Jaws is brilliant - temperamantal mechanical sharks aside!  All that water-level perspective camerawork is groundbreaking and was copied hugely in Robert Zemekis' Cast Away - go on take a look it's where the camera is half in the water half out.I am glad to see that other IMDB users love this film enough to put it where it is in the Top 250.  It may not be fresh in our memories and there may be better films out there from one aspect or another but when it comes to the best all-rounder of all time I don't think there's one to beat this.  It is so accessible and it preys on a fundamental human fear while using very human relationships to convey the story.Of all the films that I'd like to see a remake of this is the one, Here's your cast: Edward Norton - Brody, Seann William Scott - Hooper, William H Macy - Mayor Vaughan, Tommy Lee Jones - Quint, Brian Singer - Director.

reviews.review_title: Jaws Nature vs. Man 10 out of 10
reviews.content:
(Review Contains Spoilers)
There is a new police chief Brody (Roy Scheider) on Amity Island and islanders are getting ready for the summer crowds. But a newcomer has decided to join the festivities, a 25-foot great white shark. In the beginning of the film, this shark kills a skinny dipper and Brody wants to close the beaches until they can hunt it down. Brody reaches out to the Oceanic Institute and they send Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) to determine if there is a shark and what type it is. Together, Brody and Hooper try to convince the Amity mayor, Vaughn (Murry Hamilton), to close the beaches to protect the people. Vaughn will not listen; he puts profits from visitors ahead of their protection. After four people are killed, Brody gets Vaughn to agree to hire Quint (Robert Shaw) to hunt down the shark to make the beaches safe again. Brody, Hooper, and Quint sent out to take on one of natures apex predators and hope to be the ones to survive.Watching Jaws (1975) I learned that if you disrespect nature, bad things will likely happen. This theme plays out between the town, Brody, Hooper, Quint, and a great white shark. The town, led by mayor Vaughn, refuses to take the first three shark attacks seriously. Even as Hooper and Brody talk about Ben Gardner's boat being destroyed and Ben's death, mayor Vaughn will not budge. Vaughn and the town leaders' lack of respect for the shark lead them to open the beach on July 4th weekend. The shark attacks again leading to a fourth death. While it is not shown in the film, the mayor knows this event has destroyed the towns summer revenue and he signs a voucher for Brody to hire Quint, a local fisherman, to hunt down the shark.Quint is a survivor of the USS Indianapolis that carried the bomb used on Hiroshima in World War 2. Quint tells how 1,100 men went into the water after it got hit by two Japanese torpedoes, but only 316 men were rescued, and the sharks took the rest. Quint's character carries this theme by not respecting the shark. He is after revenge due to his experience in World War 2 and has a lot of shark jaw trophies in his house. Even after he sees the shark, he thinks he can outsmart and overpower the great fish. Just like Ahab in Moby Dick, his aggressive nature and lack of respect cost him both his boat and his life.Brody and Hooper are the only two people in the film that take the shark seriously. After the second attack, Brody starts reading books to learn as much as possible about sharks. As we see him flipping through the pages, we see a picture of a shark eating a scuba tank which plays a major role in the last five minutes of the film. Hooper is an oceanographer and has loved and studied sharks since he was a boy. These two men have a rough time fighting the shark, but their respect for the animal gives them the edge which allows them to survive at the end.This theme plays out also in the movie Twister (1996), where we follow two teams of scientists chasing tornados. One team is led by Dr. Jonas Miller (Cary Elwes), but he is doing it for notoriety and not for the science. The other team is led by D. Jo Harding (Helen Hunt) and Bill Harding (Bill Paxton) who are doing this research to learn as much as possible about tornadoes to help save lives. Jonas is killed due to having a lack of respect for an F5 tornado which ends up killing him. Jo and Bill, on the other hand, are rewarded as they use their knowledge and understanding of tornados to survive the last scene.Music in this film is critical to its success and helps carry the theme. The music for the shark uses a lot of low-end tones making it powerful. We do not even see the shark for the first half of the film, but whenever you hear that music you know the shark is coming. It gives you the appreciation of the power of a great white shark and makes you think twice about getting into the ocean. In the final showdown between Brody and the shark, the music flips back and forth as the two battle. When showing the shark, it is the typical Jaws theme creating suspense. As Brody grabs his gun, the music switches over to a lighthearted music giving us a sense of hope for him. As the shark does his final run at Brody, the music is playing both low end and high-end tones. The music stops as Brody fires his final shot which hits the air tank and blows up the shark. Brody ends up defeating the shark using what he saw in the book and knowing that the air tank was highly pressurized and would explode if punctured. The music goes into a light beat as the shark's body sinks.Jaws takes advantage of various cinematic points of view as well to carry the theme. Director's interpretive point of view is used brilliantly at the opening of the movie. We are literally looking out of the eyes of the shark with the Jaws theme playing in the background. We get similar views when the shark attacks the skinny dipper and the little boy. We are looking out of the eyes of the shark to the unsuspecting victims. The audience would love to warn them, but they know it would do no good. The shark has a significant advantage over the people in the water, and we get a feel for that in these shots.Objective views are used in multiple shots to show just how big and powerful the shark is compared to those it is attacking. When a man is killed in the pond area, the shot is from overhead looking down on that man desperately trying to get back into his boat after being knocked out. We see the shark come up from underneath and grab the man and drag him down into the water. This is the first time we really see the shark and it is terrifying. Objective view is also used as Quint, Brody, and Hooper head out in the Orca to hunt down the shark. In this scene, we are viewing from Quint's house through a window. In front of the window is a shark's jaw full of teeth. The Orca is in the middle of the shark's mouth foreshadowing that the shark is likely going to win against the boat.When Quint is killed, there are multiple cinematic points of views used. Objective view starts off the scene as we see the Orca from the side and the shark jumps out of the water and comes crashing down on the back of the boat. Then we have a subjective view from behind Quint. In this view we see the shark hanging off the back of the boat while Quint struggles to keep from sliding to the shark. There are multiple shots after this in an objective view as we watch Brody and Quint struggle. Quint cannot hold on and as he is sliding towards the shark, the camera switches to a director's interpretive point of view from Quint's perspective. We see from Quint's eyes as his legs slide toward the waiting shark. After the shark bites down on Quint, we go to an indirect-subjective point of view looking right at Quint's face as he screams in pain and terror. The scene ends in a subjective point of view from behind Brody and we see the shark drag Quint's dead body below water.Between the great music, great cinematography, acting and story, we are taking on an adventure as those that disrespect the shark lose out and those that take the time to learn and respect the shark survive and are victorious.
I love it so much everyone should agree sorry I am so happy for this person who came up with it they must have a lot uf money.

reviews.review_title: Just when you though it was safe to go back into the water...
reviews.content: How amazingly griping this film is. i saw the cover of this movie in a blockbuster when i was 6 or 7 and it practically called me to it. and i begged my mom to rent if for me. she saw it as a teen when it first came out and it terrified her and she didn't want to...but i won. she said i would be sorry...and i kinda was.it was absolutely terrifying! i couldn't sleep that night. i haven't been able to go in the ocean beyond knee deep since.here's my review (possible SPOILERS) first of all, a lot of people complain that you don't see the shark until over an hour and a half into the movie. well if you know anything about horror films you'll notice that it rises the feeling of fear in people when they don't see the "monster" that takes the fun away from your imagination. i think it helps the film be a better film. (it wasn't even planed) Robert, Roy, and Richard are all fabulous. Murray is great too. some people don't understand why there was more attention on the people rather than the shark. the big fight over what to do about the shark and saving the town's money shows just how arrogant and selfish people can be in that situation. i don't know what it's like to own a business, but if i was in their position i would gladly close the beach for a few days instead of promoting it, just so people can be attack then have no business at all. and the struggles between the three main characters are very realistic. poor Brody is the new police chief and has to deal with EVERYONES problems and fights to do what's in everybody's best interest. Mat Hooper, the scientist, is treated like S*** because he's richer and educated and they don't want to admit that he's right. Quinn does have that captain Abraham from Moby Dick going on but it isn't the same. he suffered a major shark attack during the war and wants revenge. the best element in the movie is the score. chills you right to the bone. who needs to see the shark when they start to play that music. i do consider this a classic because i have to watch it a few times a year at least. only classics do that to you.

reviews.review_title: One of the Best Monster movies of all time!
reviews.content: Jaws. The film that will haunt you every time you go swimming in the ocean. What a great film! Fantastic acting from Scheider, Shaw and Dreyfuss on the edge of your chair suspense (due to the memorable score by John Williams) and a superb ending.This film really hits home and tugs at the heart strings when each victim is consumed by the terrifyingly large fish that scars the lives of the victims families and engraves itself inside of them. You get close to the 3 main characters- Brody, Quint and Hooper thereby understanding what type of characters they are and how they'd react in certain situations so this shows how well Spielberg presents his interesting cast to the audience.We care about these characters and their goals to put an end to the monster's life so this makes it all the more tragic when it doesn't go to plan. Out of the three I can relate most to Hooper, who isn't used to a fisher man's life and seems to be content on focusing on the academic side of things.There are a lot of hilarious moments when Quint and Hooper verbally fight and the sarcastic and dark nature of Hooper's humour provides that light hearted side to this Horror film.The tension building up to the ending does indeed pay off, it would be a sin if Hollywood were to remake this classic as they'd never capture the great personalities of the characters or the suspenseful moments that this film brings. I give this film a 8.4/10 -highly recommended!

reviews.review_title: A Heart Pounding Thriller, A Mindless, Fun Film With A Great Concept
reviews.content: Steven Spielberg has always been a great filmmaker. He does an excellent job at making a film a lot of fun, a way of making a film exciting. Though he does have many "artistic" films like Schindler's List, he is mainly known for his exciting, fun, adventure films like "Jurassic Park," "E.T.," "Indiana Jones," and ultimately this film, he also does make some artistic films like "Schindler's List." Jaws falls in the earlier category, and although it is a mindless film that has a basic plot, Spielberg was able to pull off a true masterpiece, a fun, thrilling, suspenseful film.Spielberg's directing as always was incredible. Though he doesn't take many intellectually inclined film routes (though he does) he is able to make a film important and memorable. The acting is also a very high point in this film. The acting by Roy Scheider, Robert Shaw, and Richard Dreyfuss was incredible. They portray a great team, and have a lot of chemistry on the set. They feel like real people and a real group.Cinematography is basic. Not much to talk about here.Music is brilliant. John Williams produced a basic, yet tense theme song that reminds me of a shark's tail waving and pushing itself through the water. Though the theme is tense, most of the music in this film is cheery in a tropical way, nearly sounding like pirate music. This is an excellent film that is requirement for any movie watcher to check out. There is absolutely no reason for anyone to have not seen this movie. If you haven't seen it, you are missing out on a crucial part of film history and will be missing out on an intensely fun experience.

The movie Jaws marks a turning point in movies around the world. Not only is it thought of as one of the greatest movies of all time, but it also strikes fear in all swimmers around the globe. The magic man, Steven Spielberg did an amazing job directing a spectacular film. Jaws truly evolved movies and created summer block busters, a legacy that still runs today. Writers in Peter Benchley, Carl Gottlieb, and Howard Sackler created a style of horror that has never been seen before. What they made so scary about it was, it could happen, and has happened. In the 1916 shark attacks, these writers bring back to life the horror of what happened on that day in 1916. Although it wasn't too scary it was really an adventure of three different characters. They come together to hunt a great white shark that is terrorizing a small island of Amity. All the actors were fantastic from Roy Schieder as Police Chief Brody to Richard Dreyfuss as Matt Hooper the oceanographic institute shark expert brought in Brody to point out the key factors about the shark. Then to Murray Hamilton as the fulsome mayor that it being 4th of July only sees money throughout the situation not any public safety. And now to the churlishness of Quint, with his discordant voice, to his larger-than-life personality. He dominates every scene he's in. '' Ill find him for three but ill catch him for ten'' this is an iconic quote from Quint thatsets a tone in the movie that foreshadows that the shark will be almost impossible to catch. Another great quote comes from chief Brody and Matt Hopper, Brody: ''I used to hate the water,'' Hooper: ''I can't imagine why!'' Cleary being a sarcastic comment, since there was just a 25-foot man eating shark that killed 7 people in a span of a day, and that nearly killed them too. Sadly, now getting to the end of the movie Quint sadly gets eaten by the shark. But he doesn't go out without telling u a good tale of when he was on the USS Indianapolis explaining this only to Brody and Hooper that the ship was hit by 2 Japanese torpedoes and sunk in 12 minutes, it was right after they were going to drop the bomb on Hiroshima. There mission was so top secret that no one even knew that there were 700 men stranded in the water but then something happened. One by one men were pulled under water, they collaborated to make small pods to keep warmth and to keep the sharks away from them. 700 men went on that boat 300 came off.
Simply epic. One of the best movies ever. Wonderful to watch a good movie with good actors and no mobile phones.. Love it..

Where do I begin? Jaws was the first summer blockbuster- the film that heralded the start of an amazing career of young Steven Spielberg and the one film that single handedly caused beaches to close down that summer. Jaws has two villains. During the first half of the film, the enemy isn't the shark; it's the face of bureaucracy, as personified by the mayor. More concerned with the economic bottom line than with the possibility of someone being injured, Vaughn muzzles Martin, allowing further deaths to occur. While Martin battles Vaughn and his puppets on the town council, the shark lurks in the background, ready to take over the role of antagonist when the mayor gives way. The second half of the film is the classic man against beast, with Jaws representing the rarest of movie monsters - something that exists in the depths of the ocean (albeit typically in smaller dimensions). This, of course, is the clash for which people watch the movie, and it is handled with great skill.

Jaws, a thrilling horror film, is set on the fictitious Amity Island in the mid-seventies. The film focuses on a series of shark attacks and a subsequent shark hunt. Jaws is based on a bestselling novel by Peter Bentley, who also wrote the screenplay for the film. The groundbreaking 1975 film has won Academy Awards for Film Editing, Music, and Sound. Its cast is full of talented actors, including Roy Schneider, Robert Shaw, and Richard Dreyfuss.The acting seen in this film is phenomenal. Roy Schneider perfectly depicts the paranoid police officer from New York, Martin Brody, who is terrified of water. Schneider plays the part so well that the viewer can almost feel Brody's terror throughout the film, especially whenever he is anywhere near water. Robert Shaw is very convincing as Quint, a mad fisherman obsessed with shark hunting. Shaw's believable persona reminds me of Ahab, the crazed captain who devoted his life to the hunt for Moby Dick. Richard Dreyfuss portrays the geeky, shark-savvy "college boy" exceptionally well, adding comic relief to the otherwise morbid film with his dark sense of humor.Although Jaws was released over thirty years ago, its special effects are extremely believable. The first two shark attacks seen in the film are frightening, but not because viewers can see the actual shark; in fact, Jaws is only implied in these scenes. These shark attacks are chilling to watch because the viewer can sense the fear and pain and agony of the victim; he or she can see the water turning from blue-gray to red; the viewer can hear the shrill, desperate cries for help. The last shark attack of the film, however, is disturbing on a different level. In this scene, both the victim and Jaws are visible. It's graphic and realistic. In addition, the cadavers seen in the film aren't false-looking; the twisted remains of Jaws' victims are grisly and grotesque.I first saw Jaws in my English class when I was a junior in high school. I was expecting it to be incredibly lame, but I was pleasantly surprised. Jaws is a great movie. It's suspenseful, scary, interesting, and funny. The acting and special effects are believable. The score succeeds in "setting the scene" throughout the film. The screenplay is well-written. Steven Spielberg does a fantastic job as the director; he's very good at capturing emotion, especially fear and panic. Jaws is definitely worth seeing, even if you've never seen it before or you think it's overrated. You should give it a shot. I doubt you'll regret it.

reviews.review_title: You're gonna need a bigger boat
reviews.content: ***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** (spoilers) When Steven Spielberg was only 27 years old, a young-and-coming director, he read Peter Benchley's best-selling novel, JAWS. He read it over and over again, and finally came to the conclusion that a good movie could be made about this suspenseful book.The words "Good movie" in that sentence could be the understatement of the decade. Spielberg's 1975 suspense thriller, JAWS, is respected as one of the best movies of its genre ever to be made. It boasts a great cast, with Roy Scheider as Amity Police Chief Martin Brody, Richard Dreyfuss as Matt Hooper, a young ichthyologist who comes to help out Amity with the shark problems it has, and Robert Shaw as Quint, a crazy old sailor who has been in one battle too many. Lorraine Gary co-stars as Brody's worrier wife Ellen, and Murray Hamilton as Amity's mayor who seems to  care more about the economy of the summer resort more than the safety of the citizens.JAWS starts out simple enough. A young woman is killed in the water one morning, and Chief Brody reluctantly accepts Mayor Larry Vaughn's decision to keep the beaches open. But then the tables turn on him. When there is another attack, drastic measures are taken as the beaches are reluctantly closed by Vaughn, and many fisherman are sent to kill the shark. The fisherman do catch a man-eating tiger shark, but Matt Hooper declares that it is not the shark and proves it when he and Brody do an autopsy and find no remains of the second victim, who would still be in the shark's stomach even after a day or so. When Hooper finds a great white shark tooth in the hull of a wrecked fishing boat (then drops it when he finds something else in the hull of the boat), he declares that a Great White Shark is living off the shore of Amity Island. Mayor Vaughn won't hear of it, however, and states that the beaches will be open for the fourth of July. When there is yet another attack, Brody decides to take matters into his own hands and pay a fisherman named Quint $10,000 to catch and kill the shark. Quint decides to take Brody and Hooper along for the ride.Then comes the second half of JAWS, which takes place entirely on Quint's vessel, the ORCA. When a feeble attempt at catching the shark on hook and line fails, Quint decides to take on a different tactic. When he sees that the shark is 25 feet long and over 6,000 pounds, he decides to stick a barrel in the shark to wear him down and bring him to the surface. After one barrel, though, the shark goes under the water, and the three-man crew settle down for dinner.The next scene includes one of the longest, most memorable speeches in movie history, as Quint tells Brody and Hooper about his days on the U.S.S Indianapolis. He decribes that 1,100 soliders went into the water, but only 316 came out, as the rest either drowned or were killed by sharks, and he the crew were only rescued sfter five long days of waiting in the water. The speech tells the audience how Quint became a crazy old fisherman and why he hunts sharks for a living.After Quint's speech, the shark attacks the ORCA, which leads to the engines being slightly damaged, lights going out, and water getting everywhere. The next morning, Quint and Hooper see that the barrel is up, and try to snag it, but then the shark runs away as Brody tries to make a distress phone call to the Coast Guard. Quint stops him, however, and he then puts another two barrels into the shark. When the barrels surface, the shark gets revenge by filling the ORCA's engines even more with salt water, though Quint manages to get a third barrel into it. But as the ORCA starts to sink, everything seems hopeless.However, Hooper propses a strategy to Quint; getting into his "anti-shark cage" and trying to stab the shark with a poisonous pole in the water. To Hooper's dismay, however, he loses the pole and flees from the cage for his life as the shark rips it apart.As the shark surfaces and sinks the stern of the ORCA, Quint accidently slides down the deck and is bitten in half in a horrifying scene that shows the shark coming back to finish the job from his Indianapolis days thirty years eariler.The only person left to possibly be able to fight the shark is Brody, who is able to throw one of Hooper's "explodable" oxygen tanks into the shark's mouth, then grab Quint's M-1 rifle and take shots at the shark's mouth from the mast, trying to hit the tank. On his sixth shot, he penetrates the steel tank and blows up the shark in a scene that many people in theaters cheered on. When Hooper surfaces, he and Brody kick their way toward Amity and safely arrive, with the shark dead.It's a great story, and was also very powerfully acted. Shaw, who actually also wrote the Indianapolis speech, was easily the best actor in the movie, and I think he should have won Best Actor even over the likes of Jack Nicholson in ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST. Not to be counted out, Scheider filled in the slot of Chief Brody admirably, and the final scene where he kills the shark is amazing.I did find two flaws in JAWS, however. First off is the big one: the shark itself. Spielberg did a great job to edit out most of the scenes with the shark in it, but there were still some scenes that showed the shark as not being very good. It actually kind of looks like it's made out of rubber, and I'm not kidding. In the scene where it launches itself onto the stern of the ORCA, it looks like one of those bathtub sharks that a 3-year-old plays with, so I think the shark could have been better, even though it was only 1975, and they didn't have great special effects back then.The last flaw isn't nearly as big, and only really bad movie critics would point it out, but I thought I had to anyway. When Brody kills the shark, he shoots an oxygen tank that is lodged in its mouth, and it explodes. That isn't very realistic-though if that situation really did occur, shooting the tank MIGHT kill the shark anyway. But there wouldn't be an explosion. Quoting Spielberg, "People have believed what I've done for the past two hours. I think they'll believe what I'll show them in the last five minutes".Despite these minor flaws, JAWS was a great movie, easily one of the best of the 1970s, and it deserves to be recognized as it is today. Oh, and as for the Oscars: ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST was good and all, but give JAWS a break; it deserved at least one of the five major Oscar Awards.

Jaws (1975) was directed by Steven Spielberg and it based on the novel written by Peter Benchley of the same name. It's and old blockbuster and still one of the most famous movies ever released. It's a thriller set on Amity Island, which is a fictional summer resort island in New England.The story is about a great white sharks who terrorizes people on the 4th of July on Amity Island. Three victims get eaten before someone takes the situation in their hands. Chief Brody (Roy Scheider) the sheriff of the island, Quint (Robert Shaw) an army veteran with an astonishing shark killing career, and Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) an oceanographer with great knowledge on sharks form a crew and head with a ship to hunt the beast down. It gets more complicated than what they thought it would be and face many difficulties during their hunt.The well known Jaws soundtrack when the shark approaches the victim is one of the golden attributes of the movie, and the thing that probably even the new generations well know. But other than that little detail, the whole movie is just brilliant. The actors really give us a heartwarming feeling while on the boat, they express their passion for their jobs really well, and they really look like they are putting an effort into catching the great white.Being a 20th century movie, i was thrilled every time the shark got to show itself on the camera, which is something hard to accomplish with the technology they had at the time. I think that if the movie would have come out at the present time it would have the same success as it had back in they day, being a masterpiece in all aspects.I would recommend the movie to all the movie-lovers that wish to see the old-timers" and that don't mind seeing the screen in a retro way. Definitely still the best shark movie out there.

I saw this movie for the first time 30 years after it came out, and now I remember why I never bothered to see it in the first place: because I imagined its plot would be predictably boring, and that the shark's behavior would belie it's true nature, that is, it is not a real shark. A real shark wouldn't do the things that mechanical shark did, and I simply wasn't able to suspend my disbelief for two hours so I could enjoy this film.Like most modern films, this one has only one simple idea. Spielberg proceeds to beat you over the head with this idea: There is a big killer shark in that water! And as the film goes on, it gets bigger and bigger. I wouldn't be surprised if there was a sequel titled "Jaws Attacks the Titanic."

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest (despite the shark)
reviews.content:
We all remember the first time we saw JAWS. It is a strange quirk that a film so scary is committed to the earliest memories of so many of us.
We all remember being taunted by the score. We remember the fear and admiration when Hooper goes down in the cage, and we remember the absolute horror of Ben Gardners eyeless head screaming out at us.From its earliest screenings on TV, through the video boom and beyond, JAWS has somehow been left to wallow towards the 'family' end of the film listings. Perhaps it is Speilbergs subsequent output, or maybe it is the increasingly bad sequels that have given JAWS this peculiar 'spin'.
I would argue that the well documented production problems encountered by speilberg and his crew, not only contributed to the films success, but also helped to create this unusual positioning of the film within the public psyche. Speilberg was unable to use as much footage of the mechanical shark as he had hoped. Salt water, and the sheer ambition of the animatronics involved conspired to hold up production and force re-write after re-write. It was during this process that the films ebb and flow (apologies), evolved.
It was here that the lack of shark would manifest itself as the prolonged sense of foreboding within the film. What developed was a real sense of the fear of the unknown, and this is where much of the films success lies. It tapped into the fear of what might be in the closet, or under the bed. The monster that we know is there even if we cannot see it.It would be interesting to see if our memories of how old we were when we first watched JAWS are correct, or whether it is in re-living the real childhood experience of the hidden monster that makes us believe that we were younger than we were.It is certainly true that Speilbergs youthful brilliance, and Williams unforgettable musical motif carry what could have been an enjoyable B-movie on to a much higher cinematic plane.

reviews.review_title: Jaws portrays the hunt for a seldom seen villain, with little interruption. The films depth, particularly that of the three leading characters is endlessly entertaining
reviews.content: The ultimate adventure film, Jaws will almost certainly remain the leading title in its genre. The single founded criticism of the film, which will only increase in severity with each passing year, will be the quality of appearance of the villain. Undoubtedly, for the twenty-first century viewer, the image of the shark would do little to frighten. However, and remarkably so, the quality of the model shark has little influence on just how frightening it, and the movie, is. Why? Because it is not the thought of the shark's appearance that is most frightening, but rather the thought of what the shark will do. Too often thriller/horror films, featuring non- human antagonists rely on the image of the creature to form the climax of the film. Spillberg, instead relies on the Shark's actions to frighten the audience, and a more effective frightening of an audience has never before, or since, been seen. The film, in the words of the producers and director is a straight a-z action film, with little interruption of the realisation of the conflict and the solving of it. Thus, Jaws is a very real candidate for a superficial action film, one which as time ages it's effects, it's quality wains. Yet the performance of the cast is so incredible, that the film's depth exceeds that beyond the waters which the rouge Shark circles. Scheider plays a plagued straight man brilliantly, Dreyfus is everything a good character shouldn't be, a know it all, spoiled, arrogant, condescending, and yet this is precisely why his character is so endearing. Most of all, Shaw's outstanding performance is beyond criticism or comparison. His every scene is a highlight of the film, and his final meeting with the film's antagonist, leads the audience to question just who they're cheering for, albeit momentarily. In watching Jaws, one views perhaps one of the greatest ever cinematic artist's first true critical and commercial smash-hits. It's not his most well-rounded film. The filming is raw, the score confronting and confusing at times, the characters seem ill-developed, and scenes without the villain are spent waiting and hoping for his emergence. And yet, it is these characteristics, or more accurately these qualities, which make Jaws such an incredible film. If seeking to be entertained, watch Jaws. If seeking to be scared, watch Jaws. If seeking to see powerful acting performances, watch Jaws. If seeking to view a film alone, watch Jaws. If seeking to view a film with friends, watch Jaws. If seeking to see a frightening, confronting or grotesque monster, don't watch Jaws. If the purpose of a film is to entertain, then Jaws is the definition of a cinematic success.

The special effects when we finally see the shark... could have been better. The shark actually probably looked better in later movies, but they just weren't any good here. reviews.review_title: A cinema classic - the first blockbuster
reviews.content: I have seen this film countless times and, thinking about it, is one of the first films I remember seeing.This film came at a time when the term "blockbuster" didn't exist but it sure did start it! All the elements are there. An arduous shoot;based on a bestselling novel;never before seen effects etc.The film is based on the novel of the same name by Peter Benchley. It tells the story of a mainland cop who moves his family away from the city to a quiet island. However, his peaceful life of dealing with moaning shop keepers is shattered by an unexpected visitor...I am sure there are some youngsters out there who have not seen this picture so I am not going to say anymore about the plot. I want you to experience the terrifying opening sequence as I did and let yourself enjoy the ride! Spielberg was a newcomer to Hollywood when he made Jaws and the fact he is now regarded as one of the world's greatest directors is testament to the power of this film.Get the 30th anniversary DVD, a bag of popcorn and see it fly across the room - Jaws is cinema at it's best!

I must have watched this film a hundred times and then some. It's my favourite film, ever. I have analysed it a dozen times and there is always something new to find in it. I remember my Grandad reading the book to us years ago and not realising what it all meant. The film, released in 1975 when I was six years old, didn't make an impact on me until my local club, who gave 'big screen' film nights every Tuesday a month, played this film. I was hooked! It's the start of Spielberg's glittering career and tells the tale of a New York cop (Brody) who has become the chief of police on small island hoping for a quiet life with his wife, Ellen and two kids (here's where the book, written by Peter Benchley, and the film differ greatly). A great white shark decides it quite likes the cuisine served up by Amity Island and it becomes Brody's job to stop it. For a cop that hates the water, it's his biggest challenge ever. If you haven't seen this film, please, don't read the book first and the make comparisons... just watch the film. It's addictive, trust me!

A string of fatal shark attacks have beached on Amity Island's doorstep in the week leading up to the 4th of July weekend, the Island's biggest tourist attraction of the year. Local Deputy of Chief Police, Martin Brody (played by Roy Scheider), struggles to get the Mayor to understand that the beaches must be closed to prevent any more deaths. Unfortunately, Mayor Larry Vaughn fears the opposite; closing the beaches will ruin Amity Island's summer tourist season, the town's primary income source for the year.It's not long into the film before we and the terrified people of Amity Island discover that this creature of the sea is not one to be messed with. Unseen for the majority of the film (mainly the first half) Steven Spielberg creates a fear of the unknown. And who doesn't fear the unknown? Clever use of the camera and iconic musical score hints that danger is nearby but for the poor guy on screen, they have no idea what's lurking underneath them. It captures the feeling of helplessness I have every time I swim in the ocean, or even when I was younger just in the local swimming pool. Maybe it was Jaws that made me feel this in the first place!Throughout the film, floating objects are used to portray the sharks sense of direction. One scene in particular shows an old wooden dock being snapped out of place and dragged out to sea by the shark before turning and charging back to a panicking swimmer. By using the wooden dock not only can we see the unknown but also register it's sheer strength. It's a monster.I had to wonder who the 'villain' of this film really is. The man-eating killer shark doing what it can to get by or the 'putting everyone's life in stake for profit' Mayor. One shocking scene halfway through the film shows a crowded beach with nobody in the water. The Mayor walks over to a friend, a father with his family, and forces them to get in. They do so unwillingly, their faces read pure fear but eventually it leads to a sea filled buffet for the shark (I don't refer to the shark as Jaws because that's just the name of the film, not the shark itself). It may be shocking but it was a shockingly great way to make the Mayor even more of a douche.Martin Brody soon teams up with shark enthusiast Matt Hooper and shark hunter Quint. There's some tension between them which is escalated with the fact they are alone on a small boat out in the ocean. It creates exciting chemistry when they are risking their lives trying to catch this beast. Despite having more camera time in this part of the movie, the shark looks and moves incredibly well for a film from the 70′s. It definitely still holds up today.It's been almost 40 years since it's release and still Jaws remains as one of the best suspense/thriller film ever released. If you haven't seen this film for whatever reason you need to check it out. If you've already seen it before, maybe it's time to watch it again.
Jaws is a great classic movie that all of you should definitely see.

reviews.review_title: The original shark film still has no peer
reviews.content: Boy meets girl, girl undresses girl, shark eats girl.When the body of a girl (well, some of it) is discovered washed up on the beach of a popular summer holiday resort town, the town sheriff, Martin Brody, isn't quite prepared for the turmoil that the town is thrown into when a killer white pointer shark arrives in time for the peak holiday season.Politics, petty rivalries and individual weaknesses all combine to make the job of eliminating the shark that much harder. Meanwhile the death toll mounts. After finally convincing the townfolk of their plight Brody, a marine biologist and a seasoned fisherman set out to catch the killer shark and make the beaches safe once more. My first foray into the world of adult cinema left an indelible mark on me. I was 9 years old (how did they let me in?) when my parents took me to see this landmark film at the State Theatre in Sydney. I was quite the reader at the time and had already polished off Benchley's novel, so I thought I knew what to expect.I was flabbergasted! It was my first scary big screen experience and the sights, sounds and audience reactions were overwhelming. I was hooked! (pardon the pun).     The desensitised kids of today may scoff at the fake shark ("It's not CGE!") and may not wince at the bloodshed in this film but the suspense, drama and action should keep them in their seats.The actors held the movie together well with solid performances and it was only the magnificent 'Cuckoo's Nest' that prevented this film from scoring a 'Best Film' Oscar. I loved it and I gave it a 9 out of 10.

They're all played to perfection and become the characters. Another thing this film deserves praise on is the screenplay. It's not Tarantino or anything, but its still pretty good. One of my favorite scenes in both this film and of all cinema is when Chief Brody looks out into the ocean with determination to kill this shark. In a nutshell, Jaws is simply a masterpiece in movie-making that invests me more each time I watch it. It's an excellent movie.

This isn't a perfect movie whatsoever. But the effort behind it and how good it turned out to be make me appreciate it so much. I've never felt so immersed in a movie's atmosphere. It's as if you could smell the salt coming from the water.
I'll say it again, the BALLS it took to create an actual shark, and god, do you know how many times this stupid machine broke? It makes me appreciate it.

35 years ago it was awesome. But today the movie has such unnecessary lengths. And the actors still talk to each other like back in the fifties. Well, it is more yelling than talking. Unfortunately this is one movie that didn't make it into the presence without losing most of its power.

Having seen Jaws again for what must be the 37th time, I'm still pleased with almost all aspects of the film. The pacing is nearly perfect, the story is strong, still fairly frightening (really, after 37 times?) and the acting is good. Many of Spielberg's trademarks grace the film. Solid cinematography all around, some of which has since been taken for granted. Viewed against "Duel", its easy to see why he felt he could pull this one off, despite obvious limitations. Knowing the history of "Jaws" and seeing it again, it is hard to believe that it was as difficult to make as everybody working on the film has since stated. It feels very natural. I would speculate that it's status in film history would arguably be the same if some of the bumps along the way were apparent in the film. In retrospect, I do see moments in the film where one might suggest its hit a rough patch, but the story itself isn't perfect so I find it difficult to tell. At the same time, I don't feel that I'm doing the film justice by thinking about it heavily. Spielberg later made plenty of those, "Jaws" not being one of them. Still, it doesn't leave you brain-dead like the standard popcorn flick (i.e. "The Lost World"). This is still very much a cut above most anything like it that followed and only a bit better than "Duel", both of which are very close to my film-going heart. Spielberg has not since given us such a shock or such a fright, but almost certainly better films and better stories. I'm giving "Jaws" a 9 because it's really a sum of it's parts, and it still works on many levels.

The thing that makes Jaws so good is that it doesn't just focus on the Shark and them hunting it in the water for 2 hours. The movie has a great script from Peter Benchley (also author of Jaws). Which does focus on other things such as having the protagonist be a man fearing the water setting sail onto a boat to kill a man eating shark. And the characters are all well rounded. They have many faces shown by the actors especially in Richard Dreyfuss's potrail of Hooper. reviews.review_title: Why does Hooper not mention finding Ben Gardener's corpse?
reviews.content: When Hooper dives on Ben Gardener's wrecked boat and is investigating the hole/s in the hull, Gardener's corpse floats into view, shocking Hooper into dropping the sharks tooth, as well as his flashlight and diving knife. When Hooper swims back to his own boat he says nothing about the discovery to Chief Brody, nor does he mention the body when arguing with the Mayor about closing the beaches. Surely the fact that the shark has killed yet another person would lend weight to his opinion yet he says nothing about it. Later in the movie it is mentioned that Gardener is still "missing", even if the body floated out of the boat when it was towed in, I imagine that a police forensic examination would conclude that Gardener was killed in the attack on the boat.Any ideas on this puzzling behaviour?
