Being scary often means going outside the bounds of concrete reality. It means making something mysterious or otherworldly to attack the irrational corners of the audience's primitive instincts. Michael Meyers, Leatherface, and Pyramid Head are all excellent examples of humans or humanoid creatures that frighten us with their ambiguity. However, there is one movie that manages to truly communicate horror of the unknown in a way unlike any other. That movie is Jaws.Jaws is often considered the first modern summer blockbuster and the first mainstream shark movie. Due to that awful legacy, it's easy to forget what an impressive movie Jaws really is. There's a lot to go over, so here's the basics.The story centers around a New England summer resort town that suffers several vicious shark attacks within days of each other. And during tourist season, no less! After a community panic, an oceanographer, a blue-collar seafarer, and a yuppie police chief all board a small boat to hunt and kill the great white shark terrorising their town. Also, for simplicity's sake, I'll mostly be calling the shark "Bruce" from now on.One thing you'll need to know for viewing is that this movie is a slow burn. Most of it is the conflict between Police Chief Brody trying to shut the beach down and the mayor and his committee members trying their best to keep the beaches open for their revenue. But when the action does kick in, it doesn't disappoint. In small bursts during the first half and for most of the second, Bruce becomes the star of the show. So much so that the music and camera work starts to act as an extension of him.The iconic soundtrack by John Williams is an unforgettable part of the experience. When the shark comes around, the soundtrack comes alive as if it were its own character. Whether it be suspenseful, fearful, or even whimsical, the soundtrack is very expressive. The cinematography is the same. Aside from the iconic shots from Bruce's point of view underwater, the camerawork comes alive when he's about to strike.I think you're starting to sense a pattern. The action only really cranks up when Bruce is on the prowl. That's true, but that doesn't mean the quieter parts of the movie don't work just as well. The main trio of characters are Brody, Ichthyologist (essentially a shark-ologist) Matt Hooper, and fisherman Quint. They're a joy to watch, both as a group and on their own merits. Brody is your everyman. He's the blandest at the start, but makes up for it by going through the most change. I'll get to that later, but just know I like him. Hooper is an interesting character. His archetype is the college-educated white kid that's a bit childish despite his intelligence. He often shows an almost child-like happiness in sharing his knowledge on sharks and makes passive-aggressive remarks or funny faces at people after arguing with them. He constantly butts heads with Quint, our final part of the trio. He's a working-class fisherman with a huge sense of pride. He often makes fun of Hooper for his educated approach to things as well as his apparent softness from a cushy life "counting money." His pride also extends to the shark itself. After realizing Bruce is far too big and dangerous for the three of them, Brody attempts to contact their police force by radio. Not wanting to share his glory with anyone else, Quint destroys the radio transmitter, effectively stranding them out at sea with Bruce.Between the killings and the chaotic trio, there's a lot of tense moments in this film. I'll get to that stuff, but the sweeter moments are just as important. Early on, Brody is waiting for Hooper to come over for dinner. He's stressed with his head in his hands. He notices his son copying him, and Brody keeps shifting his hands and watching his son copy his movements. After that, he leans in and asks his son for a kiss on the cheek. When his son asks why, Brody simply says, "Because I need it." His son obliges, and Brody sends him off to bed as Hooper arrives. Ellen, Brody's wife, watches all of this with a surprised look on her face. Almost as if she's surprised that someone made Brody feel a little better. Moments like these always involve Brody. Whether it be with his family or his two crewmates, moments like this are sprinkled throughout the movie. I may just be a sucker, but giving Brody such tender moments with those around him feels very important to his character. Giving a character moments to reflect gives them room to further their arc. Valleys are just as important as peaks in storytelling.Speaking of peaks, the tension I mentioned earlier. There's a lot of it, obviously. A lot of people might like to think of Jaws as a horror movie since it's the first shark movie and those are usually straight-up horror movies. However, Jaws doesn't fit cleanly into a single category. The sheer horror of Bruce tearing apart people is a big part, yes. But I'd argue that the suspense of what he'll do is more important than the actual blood and gore itself. Seeing the viewpoint of Bruce as he closes in on a target is genuinely upsetting. Seeing him toy with Brody and the boys out at sea is exciting and scary. But tension doesn't just begin and end with the monster. There's a lot of drama in the town when Brody wants the beach closed but the mayor and various locals fight him at every turn. Even when out at sea, there's usually no harmony; With a few exceptions, the trio are constantly butting heads when Bruce isn't around to unite them behind a cause. Hell, sometimes the shark isn't enough to keep them from arguing.To be fair, Bruce seems to be an otherworldly horror, so I doubt most people wouldn't panic. But that's something interesting about Bruce. It doesn't act anything like a real shark would. It has an insatiable lust for human blood when sharks don't think humans taste that good; it is intelligent enough to lead the crew out to sea and go under the boat to evade danger; it's strong enough to drag the entire boat at an incredible speed. A lot of people see this film as the origin of our fear of sharks, but that's really only half true. While the movie most likely did popularize the idea that sharks are dangerous killing machines, our brains are why we're so susceptible to believing that when that isn't true. There's nothing cute or appealing about sharks to humans. They're giant, dead-eyed, toothy creatures. So, the caveman side of our mind immediately goes, "Oh, that's a scary thing. Scary things are dangerous to Grug. It must be a violent monster." I think the filmmakers understood the uniquely terrifying look of sharks. However, I don't think they believed that sharks really acted like the one in the movie.I think Bruce is supposed to be a demon in the form of the shark. It even makes a demonic sound after it's head is blown off and begins sinking to the ocean floor. It's meant to symbolize what Chief Brody fears most throughout the movie: the sea and it's untamed danger.The only potential technical flaw in the movie is that the shark isn't anatomically accurate. There's a part late in the movie when Hooper goes into an underwater cage to lure in and drug the shark. When he sees it in the distance, there's pre recorded footage of an actual shark that looks nothing like the animatronic. The animatoric is wider, less graceful, and much squarer. I decided to mention it here because I feel it works for the film. It's almost as if a supernatural force was toying with Hooper. Making him think he was looking at a regular shark only to terrorize him with it's true form. And the differences aren't only visual. It doesn't even eat or attack like a shark would. It acts more like a T-800 unit from The Terminator, bluntly attacking anything that remotely pisses it off but with a disturbing amount of intelligence. The shark isn't an animal. It is the incarnate of the chaotic violence of the sea personified into an intelligent being. A shark just happens to be a fittingly scary animal to take the vague form of.Only when Brody gets over his fear and outsmarts the creature can he and Hooper return home (yeah, Quint is eaten by the shark and it's genuinely upsetting to watch). The whole movie is a metaphor for Brody conquering his fear of the sea by killing one of its most horrifying inhabitants. Personally, I identify with that journey a lot. I hate the ocean for the same reason Brody does. It's big, mysterious, violent, and unpredictable. All you need to do is shrink it down, give it dead eyes and a load or jagged teeth and you have Bruce.ConclusionJaws is one of the most uniquely marvelous movies I've ever seen. Not a single cast member feels out of place, the presentation is beautiful, and the tension is well-managed. People criticize Bruce for being unrealistic. But I don't think the point of Bruce was for it to be like a real shark. Even if that was the intention, the idea that Bruce is a kind of evil spirit taking on a shark's form is much more satisfying. The strange feeling of watching a shark act so human-like and malicious add to the movie's unique strengths. People may be desensitized by the many violent and terrifying horror movies to come out since, but I think most people will still find intrigue in Bruce's unsettling behavior.Aside from that, I appreciate the softer moments between Brody and the other characters. Overall, I think this movie is great at being emotionally powerful in both a sentimental and frightening way. That's all thanks to the atmosphere the crew helped craft. This is an easy recommendation to anyone, diehard film buff or no.

The older I get the more I appreciate what wonderful film making this was. Performances all round are almost too good if that's possible, but makes me a little sad that this level of acting is not seen too often these days. Jaws will always be in my top 10.

I vote Jaws ,like 12 out of 10 stars. It is just original. You can tell the shark is fake but who cares. The script, the acting, the using the camera as a shark to build suspense....It is just great, really one of the only great shark flics I have seen. For me living in Massachusetts is cool because it's fun to go down to Martha's Vineyard and spots that can be seen in the movie, like South Beach. If you haven't seen this movie, which is odd, you have to. There will never be another shark movie that beats Jaws. Deep Blue Sea was cool, using both digital and animatronic sharks but it just didn't reach better than Jaws in my head. The second Jaws installments was okay but not as good as number one. Number 3-D was the worst-second to worst movie I ever saw. Jaws the Revenge, had a more realistic shark but acting could have been better. So I think that open water was cool but just face it Jaws is great

Since being a child the movie "Jaws" was something familiar. By simply being part of society one has heard a lot about it without watching it: the string orchestra, the fact that it invented the "anticipation"-scariness, and some conspiracy theories surrounding the movie.I avoided watching it due to the fear, that it might be 2 full hours of humans not being able to kill a shark - which in my mind seemed like a boring and unrealistic premise. On the other hand, it is a classic that I had to watch at one point in my life. With that in mind, my girlfriend and I started watching the movie in late 2020.The opening scene was good and it set the tone for the main narrative: watch out, shark dangerous. Obviously, nobody in the town would believe that it was a shark or that a shark was a real threat. After a lot of denial by smug businessman and an incompetent mayor, it is decided that the beach opens for main season. Resulting in massive head-shaking from the viewer: "The movie is only halfway, this is a bad idea".Long story short. One crazy old guy believes that the shark is not gone. Shark comes back and starts dining with a beach-view. The town people, not so keen on dipping anymore, change their minds and send the main character out on a boat with the crazy old guy to hunt the shark. The hunt is successful but surprisingly catchy and gripping. In the end, the good people win and the main storyline is solved.Overall, this movie contains a lot of known stereotypes: the smart nerd, the overwhelmed police, the smug businessman, the traumatized veteran, and the ignorant public. However, most of them were probably coined by "Jaws" in the first place. If you want something fresh, this movie should not be for you. If you want to admire a classic, please go for it. Despite the Hollywood-quality production and a lot of legendary shots, my initial concerns about the storyline held somewhat true.

This film is just amazing, the casting, the director, and all the crew that made it possible, for Spielberg's early work, it was still one of his best, this film is about a shark wandering into the shallow, warm waters of Amity Island, a somewhat isolated Island and feasting on the unexpected and unprepared islanders of Amity Island. As you can guess, the Shark will attack people, this movie brings lots of tension and action, for a movie from 1975 it was amazing and the shark looked very realistic, my favourite character was easily Quint, the expert fisherman who was loved and iconic, he seems a fearless, invincible man, lovable and funny. They unfortunately had another crack at remaking a Jaws film, but the other three, yes three! Never met up to the standards of the first one. 9/10, see this film, you won't be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Have always loved this movie ... but
reviews.content: I have always loved this movie and would highly recommend it to anyone who hasn't seen it . It's a classic that holds up overtime very well. It has lots of quotable lines and many great characters . However, it seems funny that you have a shark expert with a State of the art boat with all of the latest technology and gear yet you hire a crusty fisherman with an old boat for the job. And it doesn't make sense that on the busiest weekend of the year the chief of police who has no experience fishing and hates being out on the water would go help catch the shark, especially when you have an island full of well seasoned fisherman but that being said, it still works so well and is such a great film! This is the only one for me. Jaws 2,3,4,3D are no comparison to the first film .

reviews.review_title: An oldie, but it just seems to get better with age.
reviews.content: Watched Jaws last night for what seemed like the 1st time in eons, my DVD is one of the original region 2 transfers that would not play on certain machines - its fine with my new one though. Sat in the dark with the sound blasting out of my Denon 7.1 system (first time I think I have actually noticed how good the Dolby Digital mix is on the disc) and got to admit it I'm totally in love with the movie all over again.From the opening scenes of Chrissie taking her fatal skinny dip to the survivors paddling the makeshift raft to shore and end credits you are hooked. Yes the shark has aged badly but you will never see a more well rounded and balanced main cast, with whom you find yourself empathising and caring about.With out doubt it's the cast, the music (John Williams at his finest - the music actually becoming the shark at times, as the special effects did not always work) and the scripting that make this such a great movie.Shaw's USS Indianapolis speech (his own words by the way) is as powerful today as it was back in 1975, letting you into the mind set of Quint and his need to avenge his fallen shipmates by hunting sharks. Schneider (best role of his career by some margin) excels as the hydrophobic Brody struggling with and eventually over coming his childhood demons and Drayfus is totally compelling as the rich, eccentric marine biologist Hooper driven by his quest to understand the creatures he as worshiped since childhood.Rumour control is awash with re-make noises; please people leave it alone - because yes it's just that good.

Jaws knows exactly what it is, and fulfills its goal of being a thrilling shark movie in the best possible way. It's not a "Great" film, but the execution is flawless. The shark itself looks pretty fake, but you rarely actually see the whole shark, so it doesn't take you out of the movie. The horror/thrills comes from suspense and tension, so it's still an effective horror movie today (although not as gory as more recent films). Some scenes were so tense my eyes started stinging because I was too focused to remember to blink. Many things about the film are dated, but again, it doesn't take you out of the experience. Also, I've been told one the best thing about Jaws is the characters, and I agree. The three main characters are flawed but likeable, it's very satisfying to watch them work together as a team. This is truly a testament to Spielburg's talent; it's very easy to see how in a lesser director's hands, this film wouldn't be worth watching today. Overall, it's obvious why Jaws was America's first blockbuster, and it's definitely worth watching. I wanted to re-watch it almost as soon as I finished it the first time, and for me, that's really saying something.

reviews.review_title: I have a framed picture of Quint on my mantle.
reviews.content: Seriously I do.  This is one of the greatest movies ever.  Forget Godfather, please forget Lord of the Rings, this movie has it all.  Action, suspense, drama, a giant rubber shark.  Not to mention brilliant acting.  Richard Dreyfus, Jon Schneider, and Robert "mutha F-in'" Shaw, who is one of the best actors ever.  I live my life trying to be as salty and grizzled as Quint and know damn well I never will be.  This movie is a 10.  Do yourself a favor and watch it now.

reviews.review_title: This movie will never get old
reviews.content: This original classic movie will never get old. Everything about this movie is perfect, the build up to the hunt of Bruce the shark and especially the soundtrack. This soundtrack by John Williams is arguably one of the best soundtracks of all time. If you have never watched Jaws you are totally missing out! This movie is amazing and has great acting in it too! I have never heard of someone not liking this movie!
The film is slow and quite dull. It's like the end of a night in a club...you settle for it but never want to mention it again.

For me as a child seeing Jaws for the first time definitely left a lasting impression, I probably didn't see this movie till i was 8yrs old and remember being scared out of my wits. It wasn't until I was older that I truly appreciated what an amazing movie this really was, the acting, the directing and even the effects where something to marvel at. I guess this movie to me defined what a true Blockbuster movie should be, I'm not going to give a full review of the movie as it has had already ample of reviews and votes etc.I will say my favourite scene in the movie has to be the speech given by Quint (Robert Shaw) to chief Brody (Roy Scheider) and Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss)on board the Orca in search of the Great White. Starting of with comparing scars to Quints recollection of his time on board the USS Indianapolis and how him and his fellow crew were subjected to shark attacks when there ship sank. I found this a fascinating story and didn't realise that this in fact actually happened and the author of Jaws had incorporated it into his novel then into the movie. I will leave a link for anyone interested in having a look http://www.ussindianapolis.org/.I will finish by saying that anyone who has not seen this SHOULD as they don't make blockbusters like this anymore, try and get the 25th Anniversary edition as its packed with lots of extras.

This movie was made many years ago, yet still so many people are frightened to go in the water. This movie is directed so greatly that I don't think anyone could have done a better job. The plot is that a killer shark has been feeding on local islanders on Amity Island. So, the Chief of Police, a scientist, and a fisherman set out to kill it. The suspense that the movie builds up is incredible. This movie doesn't compare to anything from the past decade. You don't see movies like JAWS made today. The acting is done greatly. Richard Dryfuss definatly stands out in this movie. This was the highlight of Steven Spielburg's career also. This is a 10/10 movie. I will be seeing JAWS 2 in the next week or so, followed by JAWS 3, and JAWS 4, but I don't think any of them will compare even close to JAWS.** A MUST SEE

reviews.review_title: An edge of the seat thriller no matter how often you watch it
reviews.content: The scariest part about a movie based on a shark attacking the beach is the viewer doesn't get to see the shark for nearly half the movie. Combine this with the soundtrack and the now famous or rather infamous "dun dun" shark is here music and you have a recipe for a perfect thriller. I have yet to fulfill my bucketlist item of watching the film at night in a pool but we shall see. The set of the movie suffered some technical difficulties throughout filming, one of the most common being Bruce randomly leaping at crew because the gears had been damaged. All around whether making the film or watching the film, it was terrifying and remains so to this day.

reviews.review_title: What Is There Left To Say? Jaws Is A Thrilling Adventure!
reviews.content:
This film is a masterclass in how to shoot, edit, score, write, act, and direct a thriller. The characters are endearing, the comedy hits on all notes, the tension is carefully built up, the movie is tightly edited (unlike Close Encounters, which could have been saved by this film's editing choices), and the soundtrack is perfection. All the stars aligned on this one.
The Quint monologue is still bone-chilling. The father-son mimic moment is still sweet. And even though the film is terrifying at times, there's an optimistic and bouncy joy to it. Many call Jaws a horror film, and while the first half of the movie certainly uses many horror film tactics, the second half is a pure seafaring adventure film, and actually feels even more captivating than the build-up.
This is a near perfect film, and is absolutely one of Spielberg's all-time greats. Gets better every viewing.

reviews.review_title: New age horror film, bleeds fear throughout audience!
reviews.content: Steven Spielberg is a known name in the film industry, though it wasn't until after 1975 and the release of Jaws, was he a house-hold name. The intensity of the film is kept up through the entire length, until the very end. The homely town of Amity, which means friendship, is a summer town that survives off the tourists who come and enjoy their beautiful beaches until late September. To create such a horrific film, the director had to establish great exposition for the story, and the homelier the family, the better. Mr. and Mrs. Sheriff Brody, and their two boys are new to town, helping celebrate their first summer in such an attractive area. Establishing the main characters are outsiders, helps the audience understand the severity of the attacks and the danger that can come from not acting sensibly during this high- traffic season. The mystery of the shark is what keeps the senses high, even the shark expert is astounded at the discovery. Spielberg's use of open space, and overcrowding shows the chaos thoroughly through the film. The crowded beaches, give a sense of entrapment, while the open water gives a space for the unknown to strike fear within the citizens of Amity. Each characters plays an important role, the supportive wife of the Sheriff who is only doing his job, but trying to save as many as he can. The role of the mayor is important, because of his defiance, but near the end, he realizes his kids play on those beaches too, leading to a change of heart. Hooper's intelligence on the subject leads him to be one of the most reliable characters, spouting facts and threats, left and right. His certainty and his own fear creates the atmosphere Spielberg's audience is waiting for. This film is a masterpiece before, and after it's time.

reviews.review_title: Jaws is the perfect high-brow horror movie
reviews.content: Jaws was the first film to do many things- the first 100 million grosser, the first blockbuster, the film that made Steven Spielberg into a household name. This film has entered pop culture lexicon and is just about a great movie that everyone has at least heard of. The fine thing about Jaws is that the shark isn't really the villain- the bureaucracies of the small town, the mayor- the human elements are the true villainous element which Speilberg so adroitly makes us ponder about, at least in the first half. Of course there is a shark and the chase by three men is the highlight filled with great monologues and fantastic sequences. If you haven't yet (shockingly) please see Jaws.

This is the absolute definition of great blockbuster, thriller, and cinema 
This is one of the best movies of all time 
Steven Spielberg creates an amazing sense of suspense that makes this movie so good.
Long story short if you havent seen this movie get out from under whatever rock youre living under and watch it.

reviews.review_title: The first and possibly best Spielberg "touch"
reviews.content: Definitely the work of a gifted storyteller Jaws manifests its director's skills for action suspense and atmospheric recreation of a seemingly "common" or realistic environment.The sea in Jaws becomes the extraordinary terrain of a supreme clash , that between Man and an aggressive ,all powerful Nature. Though Spielberg cannot escape his tendency to create a schematic representation of good and evil , his art is so full that permeates and escapes his narrow intentions.The close to the "finale" shot of the sinking "master of the sea" is majestic and revealing of the redeeming character the "beast" possesses.Never again Spielberg managed to retain such dignity for the "evil" part in any of his next films. Robert Shaw's performance is shakingly true ,and the exceptional "wound comparing" scene achieves its great depth due to his powerful presence.

reviews.review_title: Big, Bad Shark = Great, Big Success
reviews.content: This is one of the greatest bits of filmmaking in history. Everything about this film makes it one of the best ever. The setting, the writing, the casting, the acting, and - most importantly - the believability that something like this could really happen. Just stop to think how many people wouldn't go in the water after this film because of how terrified of sharks they were. It's mind-boggling! A movie like this is so good because the audience can really transport themselves into it and become lost in it, maximizing the entertainment value of the movie. I completely lose it whenever I watch Quint's speech about the USS Indianapolis, because Shaw is so convincing in conveying the pain his character feels when recounting the horrific ordeal of the ship's crew. He immediately becomes humanized, rather than just being "that crazy old Ahab-type fellow."True, the book was a great work of literature, and there were quite a few liberties taken in the transition from page to screen, but that was necessary. Anyone who has read the book will tell you that there were things that needed to be omitted, and things that had to be altered. Hey, even Peter Benchley himself felt things needed to be changed for the adaptation, so he took the task himself. And that's why the film works just as well as the book - the same man was able to take one masterpiece and change just enough so that it became another masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: We're gonna need a bigger boat.
reviews.content: This is classic Speilberg prior to diverting to family films.  Growing up as a surfer in Australia, this is not the type of film that I would expect to be attracted to.  However, the  masterful suspense and tension draw me back time and time again. Not only is the mis-en-scene raw and unpolished but it is at the same time slick in only the way directors seem to be able to accomplish in their youth. Under no circumstances watch this film whilst on holidays at the beach or you won't go in the water.

Jaws is a classic for the ages. It is a film of consumate terror and suspense. The film moves at a fast pace as the shark attacks a number of people . It is not even seen for about 80 minutes, and the camera techniques make it's earlier attacks all the more terrifying.John Williams haunting score adds to the mood.it stars Roy Schieder, Robert Shaw and Richard Dreyfuss ****/****

I first saw Jaws when I was 6 years of age. After that I was too traumatised and frightened to watch it again, until now, 25 years later.
The movie has really stood the test of time; the shark doesn't look too fake and it's still as realistic as ever. This could actually happen in real life, which is what makes the movie so terrifying. I am a huge horror fan and have watched all sorts of horror movies, it seems to be a trend these days to capture maximum amounts of blood and suffering on camera to equate to a decent horror movie. This annoys me as a horror fan, as I feel that true horror is built through the unknown, suspense and the feeling of impending doom. Jaws captures all of these components with ease, hence why I would call it the scariest movie I have ever seen. The opening scene is the most horrific scene I have ever seen, yet you don't actually see any blood or what is killing the girl. Then you barely see the shark until the end of the movie, which is a stroke of genius from Spielberg. Too many movies force feed the audience these days, and require little to no mental effort from the viewer to imagine things or to try to analyse exactly what is going on. Jaws engages your imagination right from the beginning and makes you actually think about what is going on, what will happen next and you have an emotional link to the characters. You care about them and can feel their fear and suffering through the screen.
A must see movie. As a horror fan it is the only movie that I refused to watch for 25 years as it was so effective in scaring me.
This movie is a classic but i don't like movies of animals assassin. The epic sound This movie is perfect

E jaws the name itself get the genre of the movie , i dont know how many times i have watched this beautiful suspence thriller more over the suspence each shots of the movie is outstandin according to other thrillers.

When i first looked at the cover of this movie i thought yes this is the one me and i was right. Jaws is the number one movie of all time. A police chief a scientist and a grizzled sailor all set out to kill a shark that is terrorising amity island. The shark looks so realistic. You just wont get bored of this movie even watching 20 times or more. If you don't like sharks that much you will definitely love this movie. Roy Scheider plays a brilliant part as Martin Brody and his character actually suits him. This movie will have you on the edge of your seat waiting to find out whether or not they will kill the shark. The front cover makes a terrific job of the viewer interested in the film.

I watched Jaws when I was 5 years old and it scared the hell out of me! I love it til this day..
Jaws will make you afraid to go in the ocean, river, lake, pool, bathtub...pretty much any body of water!
One of the best suspense movies ever made in my opinion!

I First saw this movie when I was little but this didn't scare me at all because of how awesome it is. The time and effort that Steve put in this film just amazes me because no other directer put this much effort into a movie. Despite how long Bruce not working every time it was in the water he never gave up and moved to universal and film it in the back lot with a green screen. And because of this it was a lot more scary because you new that the shark was their but you couldn't see it so it provided suspense. The idea of using a mechanical shark in the ocean seemed easy to do at first but it failed so many times but with the expertise of Steven, he made the movie look awesome. Last but not least Quints Indianapolis speech was the best speech in movie history and Brody's line "We're gonna need a bigger boat" is the most iconic line in the movie and second best line out of all the movies next to Darth Vader's line "I am you're father". In the end Jaws was a awesome movie and even in 2013 it is still better then most shark movies.

I watch this movie as often as I get the chance. Seeing it again at the drive-in theater the summer of 2020 made the whole pandemic worth it. Might not be the best movie ever made, but it probably is the greatest movie ever made.At least, as far as I'm concerned this is the best moviegoing experience money can buy. One of those films that they just seem determined not to make anymore. Story, characters, action, substance, Spielberg's delicious cinematography, and of course to top it all off John Williams treats us to the beautiful score which netted him the MVP award in the year the film came out. Watch it, watch it again, and for best results project it on the biggest surface you can find.

When I first saw this film it had an enormous impact on me and I still think that it is one of the best films ever made. One of the things I like in this film is the use of obviously 'real' townsfolk in many of the scenes: it's hard to imagine Spielberg doing this now. I'm sure even the most minor character in his recent movies are played by actual actors. I think that this is a shame as, rather than reducing the worth of the film, using real people in some of the smaller roles added verisimilitude to the story. The direction, music and acting in JAWS are all very, very top-notch. This well-crafted film is outstanding. Simply outstanding.

reviews.review_title: I'm guessing most of those who "hated" it...
reviews.content: ...only saw it as a rental. One critic even pointed out that this is a movie that needs to be seen in a theater. WELL, DUH!!! I saw it during it's first theatrical release, and to see this as a DVD or VHS rental is a waste of time. The only way to enjoy it the first time is in a room full of other virgin viewers while seeing it on the big screen. The initial view of the shark (along with the "head" shot preceding it-you know the one I'm talking about) got such an incredible reaction from the theater...people literally screamed and laughed from the release of pent-up adrenaline following those scenes. You can't possibly re-create the feeling, even on a 60" HDTV. Spielberg tapped a vein when he picked his villain---we're not talking some imaginary fiend like Godzilla or King Kong. Viewers in '75 could relate here because these things did (and do) exist. A thriller works better when one can put themselves in the place of the lead actors.

Honestly, I thought this movie was gonna be bad. When I saw a preview of it, I thought it was just one of those low budget movies with a fake looking shark. I was wondering why it was such a classic. Well, I saw it on HBO a few years ago and damn, was I wrong.I watched it when I was probably 13 or 14. I easily scare but this one really got to me. I never thought that a movie about a shark terrorizing people would be so scary. My heart was pounding while watching the movie. Heck, I even had a nightmare the night after watching it. It was so horrible that I woke up with tears in my eyes. That had never happened to me so it was a real shocker. Definitely recommend this movie to all thrill-seekers.

reviews.review_title: The Greatest Film Ever Made....(In My Opinion, That Is!)
reviews.content: Straight out the gate , I must admit that I love this Movie!! Ever since I first saw it at the age of 3 when it was premiered on TV. I have watched Jaws more times than any other film, and I have seen a lot. This film has everything you could want from a movie, thrills, chills and excitement, as well as a great story and some damn fine acting from three of the best of they're times. The scenery, Camera- work and pacing are all top notch, but then again would you expect anything less from a Master Film Maker like Spielberg?As i mentioned previously, the actors in this movie are all excellent, especially the three main characters Brody, Hooper and the excellent Quint. Roy Scheider is great as the put upon town sheriff Martin Brody, and a Young Richard Dreyfuss has just enough smart ass knowledge to be likable as Matt Hooper, But undoubtedly the greatest role went to Robert Shaw who plays the hard drinking, abrasively salty sea Captain Samuel Quint, the movies own take on Captain Ahab!Other standout roles are Lorraine Gary as Brody's long suffering Wife Ellen and Murray Hamilton as the weasel like Town Mayor Larry Vaughne.Then of course we must mention Bruce.... The name given to the much maligned mechanical shark that was used in this movie by Spielberg is also the name of his Lawyer. Much has been written about the nightmare the crew had filming out at sea with a shark that didn't want to stop sinking etc, but in the end great craftsmanship made it all work out for the better.I hold this movie in very high regard and would recommend it to anyone wanting a good time with a few scares here and there along the way.10/10

Who would of thought a 7ft plastic shark could of sent the planet on red alert whenever considering a dip in the ocean.Well that's what Jaws managed to achieve back in the mid 70's and no film has ever equalled that kind of fear factor.With so many memorable scenes (one-eyed head in hole, you're gonna need a bigger boat, drunken war stories and getting eaten) the film has everything.Yeah it looks dated now and yeah it's not going to make you fearful of the ocean anymore but everyone will agree when I say that film still lingers in my mind the first time I saw it 36yrs ago!!I would just like to know how my folks managed to smuggle me into an x rated film back then!? (They said they couldn't find a babysitter...)

I love everything about this film. I have no idea how many times I have watched it, but I can almost recite the entire film from memory even if I leave it a few years before seeing it again.The 3 main characters are really interesting and believable. Such an amazing film could never get made these days as CGI, fast music and muscle clad beefcakes is all that's on offer.

reviews.review_title: A moving that started it all!
reviews.content: I don't see how people can see this film as anything but a cinematic sensation, even by today's standards the use of camera angles to capture the magic moments in this film are unbelievable. Of course the shark is nothing like the special effects you see on avatar but considering the age of this film I would say that the shark is still pretty believable. This film should be seen by anyone before they die, it is not just a story about a man eat shark but symbolises facing fears and human nature. Steven Spielberg strikes again with another break taking movie with moving acting from Roy Scheider, Robert Shaw and Richard Dreyfuss.

Jaws is an incredible movie. So good in fact, I have always had a fear of the ocean ever since. I will not go snorkeling, surfing, or scuba diving because of it.The casting was superb. The greatest compliment one can pay to an Actor is---that they truly became the character in question. Robert Shaw could not have been better. Roy Sheider and Richard Dryfuss were equally outstanding. They just don't make em' like this anymore. No movie has ever equalled the downright hysteria that this 'Jaws' created back in the Summer of 75'.....If a bigger blockbuster comes along---I hope I'm around to see it. Some movies may have grossed more $ dollars than "Jaws" since its release--but don't forget....it only cost $1 to see it back then ! I give 'JAWS' a 10.And you will never see me in the ocean.

Jaws was a good movie. I cant give my favorite parts because they were all so good. Jaws 2 was okay, I guess. What's the best Jaws movie to you? What do you think? I honestly think the first one is the best and I will always think that. And even if I liked another one this is bout JAWS. well I like Jaws. I do not see it often though but that's alright. reviews.review_title: The Best Jaws Movie and the Only Good One IMO
reviews.content: Jaws 1 is the only Jaws movie I would actually watch. The movie has everything, gore, screams, frights and everything you could possibly want in a horror movie. It all starts when Crissie Watkins goes out for a late night swim and is killed by a shark. The mayor keeps the beaches open, and as a result, a young boy is killed next. Next comes a frenzy of people wanting to kill the shark for a reward and they kill the wrong shark. On Independence Day, a prank by two boys takes a scary turn when the shark gets into the estuary and eats a man and almost kills 3 boys, knocking one unconscious. Police Chief Martin Brody, Oceanologist Matt Hooper and Grizzled Fisherman Quint go on a dangerous mission to kill the shark. The shark is revealed to be a twenty five footer and as the men attempt to kill it, many things go wrong and its a fight for survival. This is horror at its best. Whoever says it isn't horror is pure stupid because this movie is possibly the scariest I have ever seen. I wouldn't watch the sequels, as they aren't that good, but Jaws 1 is a great Summer blockbuster that will frighten many generations to come.

reviews.review_title: Jaws - A Film Ahead of its Time
reviews.content: Steven Spielberg's Jaws is certainly unlike any film I have seen before. Though I have seen it before viewing it in this class, it was a refresher on how ahead of its time it really was. With everything from the special effects to the sound effects to the believable props, it convinces the audience they should be on the lookout for sharks the next time they are in the ocean (even though it rarely happens in real life). Though this film is classified as adventure, drama, and thriller, I think it should be classified as more of a thriller than anything else. I say this purely because of the scenes where people are swimming in the ocean and have no idea there is a shark creeping up on them. This causes the audience to feel "thrilled" and scared for the victim but they cannot do anything about it. These scenes kind of reminded me of Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho. Even though the plots are completely different, both films portray the fact that the worst things can happen to us when we are most vulnerable. Whether it is in the shower, when we are sleeping, or trying to enjoy vacation, these films make some of us afraid to go through with every day tasks even though we should not be. Aside from the plot, I am impressed with how the film took off. For example, I cannot imagine going to a public pool and not hearing a kid sneak up on his/her friend while humming the Jaws "first victim" tune. To this day, people are still making Jaws references and that truly shows how big of an impact it made on history.

Steven Spielberg's "Jaws" is such a great classic for many reasons. It is more than just a an over dramatized shark film, it has substance and cinematic elements that make it a truly great and lasting classic. What makes "Jaws" so engaging is the fact that it is packed full of suspense.The film starts off strong with it's opening scene and first attack. The audience already knows something bad is going to happen to the skinny dipping woman due to the film's initial focus, however, the most wonderful part of it all is that the shark is not shown at all in this scene. The feeling of suspense was solely gained from the terrifying silence, the vast openness of the dark ocean, and the incredibly vulnerable shots of the girls legs dangling from underneath the water. The fact that the monster is not shown right away builds suspense in the film to such a high level, providing a fear of the unknown that affects the viewers for much of the film. Another huge factor of Jaws that provides suspense is the theme song. Each scene that shark was in the theme song was also present, which forces the viewers to correlate the song with danger. The song itself builds up by starting slower and increasing in speed, which creates a sense of suspense along with the other elements within a given scene. Overall, Jaws is such a classic film due to its innovation in the creation of suspense in film. Spielberg did an amazing job creating suspense for the viewers through several elements including sound and visuals.

reviews.review_title: Jaws Is One of The Most Suspenseful Films of All Time
reviews.content: Jaws is so much more than your average horror/thriller film you see today and this movie is 43 years old! The way Spielberg helms the film is unbelievable. Considering this is one of his first films is incredible. I can only imagine how audiences reacted in 1975 when this film first came out. Additionally John Williams score is one of the best and most suspenseful ever. The way the film blends with the music with the visuals is very smooth and gives off a greater sense of dread whenever the shark is lurking in the waters below. The performances in this film are also sensational all around especially from Robert Shaw as quint, a crusty old sailor who was my personal favourite character in the movie. The only issues I have with this film are little nitpicks that I wont spoil for you. Besides that this film is exceptional and I would highly recommend this to anyone who loves movies as much as I do. That is unless you've already seen it then of course, give it another watch you wont regret it.

This Movie is more then a Movie. This Movie is pure life! Actors are great, Story is great and Music is Masterpiece! Sad, this Masterpiece Movie has "only" today 8.0. And stupid Movies like Aliens overrated with 8.3...

This is one of my all time favorite movies. I think Spielberg did a great job of directing this movie especially with the special effects available in the 70's. This was the first movie to reach $100 million dollars and if it came out today it would have made a lot more. Jaws is an excellent movie that includes a wonderful cast of characters. Robert Shaw was awesome portraying the character of Quint. It is also neat to see a young Richard Dreyfuss play the geeky marine biologist. Roy Scheiner was good in both Jaws and Jaws 2. A scary scene for me in this movie is when Quint tells his story of the sailors on the U.S.S. Independence being eaten by sharks. Another scary scene is when Jaws raises the boat up and Quint slides into his mouth. This is a movie that I have seen over twenty times and every time it comes on TV I still watch it. Finally the music used in this movie is still recognized in today's society.
It is a very old movie that makes it really funny to watch there are more but i didn't saw all of them so maybe on day i will watch it and type something about it to.

This Movie Keeped Me Asking Questions! Is There A Jaws??? This Movie Is Like Deep Blue Sea! Scary! Trust Me! You Will Not Want To Go In The Water Again! The Movie Was Really A Big Hit! I Give It A 10 For Scaryness! This Movie Really Is A Good Movie! A MUST SEE Movie!

reviews.review_title: The beginning of natural horror movies
reviews.content: Jaws is the only movie (and the exorcist too) that made me sleep completely covered with my sheets, thinking that great white was about to jump over my bed... when, 25 years after i watched "deep blue sea", i could understand that "jaws" is a masterpiece and not only because they managed to create that monster with such limited resources, but because of the spectacular performances by Shaw, Scheider and Dreyfuss.  In a few words... those who haven't watched this movie should do it NOW and understand why is a classic that should be in the list of the 20 best films of all time.

For all those who have never seen this movie because you thought it was just another dumb man-vs-beast movie, you are missing out.  Sure, it spawned a series of simply awful sequels and an entire genre of stupid ripoffs (Orca, Deep Blue Sea, etc).  But the original Jaws is a real masterpiece, well worth getting the DVD for.  Top notch acting, a surprisingly intelligent and funny script, expertly directed by a then very young and inexperienced Spielberg.  The shark isn't the point, general fear of the unknown is.  Top notch.

reviews.review_title: Includes one of my all time favourite scenes ...
reviews.content: ... which is when the two old men try to get the shark with a chain and a big piece of meat. Suddenly the chain is taken by something underwater and the whole stage is pulled away from the shore. When I first saw that I thought "nice idea". But when that stage suddenly turns and is going towards the swimming man I was about to leave the theatre. I even lifted my feet when the man couldn't leave the water. Excellent.

This film is a true masterpiece
From the opening scene to the last 45 minutes are pure cinema.
John Williams score is the equivalent to the music for psycho.
Matt hooper, Chief Brody and quint have unbelievable chemistry and are so much fun to watch.
This film is more than just a shark movie. Many fans would agree their favourite scenes may not even have the shark in it.

reviews.review_title: In my Top 10 Movies of all time
reviews.content: JAWS is an experience like no other, and one the greatest movies of all time.

I understand why other people might like Jaws. It's all about the tension present all throughout the movie. You don't know when or how the shark will strike. You just know it will. Sadly, there is just too much tension for me to handle. At first I felt involved, but as the plot progressed, I just hoped the shark would show up and eat everyone, so that the thing could be over with. Just not my cup of tea.

***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** A Superb Horror Classic!  It is hard to find something wrong with this film. Personally, I would classify it as a suspense thriller,  because of the reality factor of a great white shark that has got to be exterminated.  A horror involves inconceivable creatures from beyond like FREDDY in NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET or DRACULA.JAWS awakens a fear in all of us that is familiar ( perhaps that explains the popularity of the film) which is further accentuated by that spine-chilling musical score when the shark is about to attack. Perhaps this is only my imagination,  but you won't see smiles on people's faces when they see JAWS,  because they recognise the familiar fear of standing waist-deep in water or paddling with a surfboard without really knowing the territory beneath them.This is of course where DEEP BLUE SEA fails terribly.  People actually laugh at DBS, because they know they are in for something like:   Shark meets Frankenstein versus Alien on the set of THE ABYSS with crappy computer graphics.SPOILER WARNINGIf  I'm forced to find something wrong with JAWS  then there would be this one scene where the shark leaps out of the water and actually bumps against the backside of Quint's  boat with its stomach.  It is a very short scene in the last 20 minutes of the film,  but the `mechanical man-made' shark is very clear in this scene.Quint was also a tough character,  but why did the shark had to devour him? In my opinion he should have lived.SPOILER ENDNevertheless,  JAWS is the Classic shark horror of all times!9 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: One of those movies that stand the test of time
reviews.content: Really incredible...it's a movie that really doesn't seem dated. Sure the a couple vehicles here and there remind you you're not in the 21st century but outside of that it's really one of the few 10 of 10 movies.You can watch it every day and at some point you can't help to stop and watch a certain part again like it's the first time.The HD version looks really good and can only imagine Spielberg did this with a 3 million dollar budget if he had unlimited funds.If he ever thought of doing a remake someone should give him a blank check.Top 10 movie ever!!!

Spielberg has made many of the most well known films of the last 50 years. Jaws is in my opinion not only his best movie, but the best film ever made. I cannot think of a single flaw in the movie. The most obvious part of it: the shark. Everything about the shark and the attacks are handled so perfectly and masterfully. It is scary without showing too much, and it has excellent payoff when there is the reveal at the end. The characters in this movie all feel like real people and are all enjoyable to spend time with. The three main characters (Brody, Quint, and Hooper) have amazing chemistry together and are just as interesting as the shark. The dialogue is perfect. I cannot fault the script at all. The score is absolutely iconic, you can't find anyone who doesn't know the Jaws theme. The ending of the movie is intense and perfect, and is really just a great end to a perfect movie. I recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys suspense or dramas. This movie is a good thriller, while also having enough character drama to carry emotion along with the suspense.

reviews.review_title: Good film making, bad accuracy and storytelling about sharks
reviews.content: In a time when people gave zero importance to environment, animal welfare and even the legitimacy of the storytelling, all that is left is to evaluate the cinematography aspects.Considering the resources available in 1975, Spielberg and the producers managed to create a very intense sense of suspense and thrill. Acting is only good from my perspective.But what made me rate it 3/10 is how evil this film created not only for the species of the matter, but for the whole ocean ecosystem. This is the single piece of media created a whole panic in the population around sharks. Lots and lots of specimens have been slaughtered just "for sports" because it became cool and manly to be a shark killer.The lack of commitment to the true behavior of the species made it look diabolic. Sharks are not man eaters, they don't even appreciate human flesh. We lack fat and meat for them. They don't carry the feeling of anger, they don't kill for fun, they don't eat wood, boat parts, license plates. And they're not as huge as the movie portraits.It's ok, film industry needs a villain. But today we see the film industry can also be the villain for a whole species. The amount of shark species under threat of extinction or already extinct is uncountable.Thank you mr. Spielberg.

reviews.review_title: Best film ever made. In spite of the rubber shark.
reviews.content: I felt compelled to write a review as the previous half dozen reviews of JAWS are laughable. The reviewers clearly do not know what a quality film is. And JAWS is a quality film. Its not a horror film - its a thriller. Suspense and shocks perfectly paced are what it is about. That and some fantastic performances. Robert Shaw produces the performance of his life. Over the top - perhaps but he pulls it off and it is impossible to take your eyes off him. A previous reviewer expressed disappointment that 'the genius behind Men in Black' produced this poor film. I stopped reading that review right there. JAWS is genius film making. I have watched it many dozens of times now and I can never stop watching until it is finished. Maybe there are not enough boobs and explosions (2 boobs on a shark victim and one explosion) for people brought up on pap like Transformers but this is the real deal. The greatest film ever made IMHO.
I've been putting this movie off for YEARS. finally watched it and yea... she deserves the praise (the shark). she's that girl !

This movie has all of the unique charms to make one want to see it over and over.  Whenver this movie comes on TV, I watch it.  So, I would guess I've viewed Jaws at least a dozen times.  Other than the plot, which is enough to make this a classic, I believe Robert Shaw's performance will always be remembered.

The hardest decision I have ever made in my life was whether to watch Jaws or Jurassic Park as both were on TV at the same time One of Spielberg's first movies yet one of his most memorable, Jaws will forever be known as the greatest shark thriller ever made. Let's face it every other shark movie since Jaws has been a dud (with the exception of Jaws 2).Quint as the iconic captain of the ship, Chief Brody as the police chief, and Hooper as the scientist all find themselves fighting for their lives from the shark known to the cast and crew as "Bruce." Jaws basically coined the phrase, "We're going to need a bigger boat" Spielberg, frustrated by the mechanical shark's ongoing mechanical failures relied on using the camera as the point of view of the shark. This added an element of suspense that was topped by no other movie.Spielberg somehow found a way to make this movie work and created a film that gave all viewers a fascination with sharks. I will always remember watching this movie with my parents on VHS (yeahVHS!) and having to close my eyes every time I heard "dun dun..dun dun."

Jaws captivated audience when it was released. It struck fear into the hearts of children (and some adults alike). That's all well and good in the seventies, but what about the present day. Most films from that era, with the exception of Star Wars and a few others, have dated horribly, but not so Jaws. Okay, so you may not be as frightened as you may have been as a kid, but as adults, we can all appreciate Steven's Spielberg's talent.The tension, the suspense, the fear, all of the aspects from the book are here, but the director has also borough photography, music, and superb acting to the movie / film. There is no need to write a long review, just watch the film yourself, and be amazed. Then, read the book, and watch the film all over again. I give the film 9/10, one point being deducted for a pretty rubbish shark. I think we should not have seen the shark until the very end, but that's just my opinion.Simply a masterpiece, every bit of it...

reviews.review_title: The greatest shark movie of all time!
reviews.content: Jaws was Steven Spielberg's directorial debut, and it really put him on the Hollywood spotlight. Basically, a great white shark begins attacking beach-goers on the small town of Amity Island. As more and more people die, a fisherman (Quint), the chief of police (Brody), and an oceanic expert (Hooper) set out to catch the beast. It ends with Quint being eaten alive by the shark and Hooper goes into a shark cage to try to poison the shark but the shark attacks him and he merely escapes. Finally, Brody kills the shark by putting a compressed air tank into the shark's mouth and shooting it so it blows up in a slow-motion, bloody explosion of epic proportions! This is my favorite movie of all time, and if you've seen this movie, you'd know exactly why. If you haven't seen this movie, do yourself a favor and go see it! It's worth it! Well guys, that's my review! See ya later!

The first summer blockbuster and it shows why. I have lost track the number of times I had seen this movie and each time you notice something new in the film.
Yes, it may look a bit outdated when compared to the high-tec movies that you get
nowadays but what it comes down to is the acting and the effort that was put into constructing the beast. This is one movie that can never be remade regardless
of who the actors are or how fancy the CGI is

Steven Spielberg captures the thriller aspect of Jaws in different elements than ever seen before in 1975, when this film was released. Although it was noted that the production costs were going over budget and there seemed to be many malfunctions with the robotic sharks, there would be a big surplus. The editing done to capture the camera work between the great white shark and people being terrorized was unique during the time this film was released. It is considered a classic also for the soundtrack to create tension for viewers watching the film and anticipating what will happen for the survival of the characters after encountering a shark. Overall Jaws had the highest grossing film of all time until other well-recognized films would top this. It is difficult for the audience to miss the camera work of extreme close-ups between the characters in the film and the close up of the sharks as the suspense is built throughout. Steven Spielberg took this creativity of the staging for this film and worked with the elements of water. Spielberg generally avoided low-key lighting during the film so viewers could clearly see the distance of the shark and it's victims. He took this film to the next level of shocking viewers using a soundtrack that keeps the audience on its toes for what will happen next as the camera zooms in to the shark. Actors, Roy Scheider, Robert Shaw, and Richard Dreyfuss worked incredibly well together that will have the audience anticipate what will happen as they encounter the great white shark.

reviews.review_title: Perfect Blend of Cinema and Sound
reviews.content: Jaws, directed by Steven Spielberg in 1975, is considered a Hollywood classic that transcends generations of movie lovers. From the film's dynamic soundtrack to the blood-tinged beach, Jaws set the standard for shark thrillers and created a genre that recognized the appeal of this predator bound to the ocean. The soundtrack alone is recognized within two notes. When John Williams created the iconic score, it set hearts pounding and determined the arrival of the man-eating Great White. The audience sees themselves in Chief Brody, a man who strives to protect his family, his community, and the unsuspecting public from the predatory shark lurking in the shallows. Spielberg allows the audience to experience the turmoil in Brody's mind as he faces opposition from city council members. We feel Brody's terror with each shark attack and how powerless he feels against it. We sense his desperation as he hires Quint, the strange fisherman with a tragic past, to slay the beast ravaging the island. As Brody sets aside his fear of the ocean, the audience joins his quest to comb the ocean for the killer with a determination that has us on the edge of our seats. With every close call, near miss, and shot fired, the audience is drawn deeper and deeper into the hunt for Jaws. From the opening credits, Williams builds our suspense with each note, as Spielberg constructs each shot to create a seamless narrative and a cinematic experience that is not easily forgotten.

reviews.review_title: A shark problem is among the town of Amity Island. The chief of police, Broddy, does everything in his power to take down this deadly shark.
reviews.content: SPOILER ALERTJaws is a great movie for its time. Stephen Spielberg builds suspense in a way like no other. Given the tile of the movie and trailers you pretty much know what the movie is about. In the beginning of the movie there is an underscore of suspenseful music and underwater shots that move threw people's legs as they are swimming in the ocean implying that there is shark coming to attack, though the shark is never revealed. Not only does the music build suspense but not revealing the shark does as well. There are two incidences where the shark attacks but is not seen. That keep the audience on their toes wanting to see the shark making the reveal of the shark epic. The music isn't the only thing that built up the suspense. The use of shot reverse shot between the chief and the ocean made you worry that shark was going to strike again. Also, in the second half of the movie, where the tree guys were hunting the shark, silence and the openness of the big ocean and the one boat was the key to the suspense of the film. The audience knows the shark would show up but not when because of the silence. This movie also shows character development. The chief for example hated the water in the beginning of the movie but is the one to defeat the shark in the end. After being on the boat together for a while, the three guys developed a relationship. Hooper and Broddy already had a friendship going, but weren't too fond of Quint. It was nice to see the relationship and trust eventually grow over time. This suspenseful movie is fun to watch not just because it keeps the audience on their toes, but because of the beauty of the beach and water and the great special effects of the shark.

"I can do anything I want, I am the Chief of police." Says Chief Brody on the shark terror running through his town. An instant classic directed by Steven Spielberg in 1975 engaging everyone that watches this film. This film exhibits teamwork, conflict, and greed, which really sets the stage for, films in the future. Starting with two people that were asking themselves this very question of ethics or money? Two very popular things that are still going on in today's world. Almost every decision in business today revolves around that and we saw the Chief want to look out for the betterment of the people whereas his counterpart the mayor was concerned with money and greed. It leaves the audience to pick a side, which many of us do throughout the film and stick to it. We root for one or the other and hope their way goes right. Spielberg, keeps the audience guessing until the very end, while the events are unfolding we do not know until the end how this story will play out is the mark of a good film. In many of today's films we see the men vs. nature conflict- this is one of the films that broke into the scene and really hit a home run with it. Almost every major film deals with a monster, animal, or some creature and this is a true Dave vs. Goliath story. When it comes to Jaws vs. Chief Brody's team it is an instant thriller that keeps the audience on the edge of their seat!

When you hear the name Steven Spielberg, a few excellent films come to mind: Saving Private Ryan, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Schindler's List, and last but most definitely not least Jaws. Jaws has been captivating audiences since it's release in 1975, the film has survived the test of time for a few reasons; for instance the structure of a strong cast. The film is lead by Roy Scheider who does a spectacular job of telling the story of lead character Chief Martin Brody, he is able to use his emotion in the film to tell the audience that there is more than what meets the eye of Chief Brody. The other shining light acting wise in this film is the star Richard Dreyfuss and his portrayal of Matt Hooper; Dreyfuss truly establishes himself as a top tier actor in this film even though it isn't a film where he has the lead role. Dreyfuss exhibits something that is truly difficult to show, and that is believable body language throughout the film, which is what separates high-caliber acting from just average acting. The acting itself isn't the only thing to carry this film into greatness, the score of this film is what truly brings this film into fruition. The score by John Williams is iconic in a way itself.The score for Jaws is a score that will live on in film history as it is the perfect culmination of story telling and emotion inducing. Everyone recognizes the suspenseful music that goes on throughout the film, and it tells two stories one of the story of the main character, the Shark, and then one of the victims; it portrays the shark as an unstoppable force and it creates an atmosphere which is overpowering to us humans that aren't so relentless. What makes this film truly stand out is the subject manner in the film. Jaws brings out the wrath of one of mother nature's children and causes the fear that is generated from this film to be real; it does something many films have tried to do and some films are still trying to do and it creates a real fear using real-world monsters. Jaws is and will continue to be a contributing factor in the history of film for all these reasons and solidifies the thriller genre as a very important one.

reviews.review_title: Greatest movie i have ever seen
reviews.content: Everything about this movie is perfect. The directing by Steven Spielberg is phenomenal. The acting is incredible and the score by John Williams is nothing less than legendary. I have seen this movie at least 30 times and it never gets old. Every scene has a purpose and the film keeps building up and up with terror and suspense. Everything that is great about film can be seen in Jaws. Definitely my favorite movie of all time.

reviews.review_title: It is as if God created the devil and gave him...Jaws.
reviews.content: Amazing film and definitely deserved more Oscars. From start to finish, superb direction from Spielberg with some terrifying moments brought to life and sends shivers up the spine. The dynamic trio of Scheider, Shaw and Dreyfuss allows us to access laughter, terror, love and every emotion possible which is often hard to do in a thriller like this. The Effects are excellent with a shark that looked realistic enough for me! Some people have criticised it and said that it would be better if done by CG but as in the case of Spielberg's other masterpiece E.T sometimes creating the actual model itself brings the best out of actors. But for me what was personally responsible for most of the film's success was the chilling score which becomes the voice and character of the shark. A well deserved Oscar for John Williams.

reviews.review_title: A Classic worth watching over and over again
reviews.content: I remember the lines around the block on this blockbuster and I lived on Long Island and went deep sea shark fishing as a kid.. Well done! Well done. Timeless.

Wow now this is a fun movie. you know there is a terror that you can never see, yet its good. I could never go swimming after I saw this movie. Heh the girl who goes swimming in the water nude. lol classic, just asking to get eaten. You know one person I really like in these kinds of movies, is the main guy who is trying to convince everyone there's a shark, yet nobody listens. The hunt at the end was good too, lots of fun cause the guys have no idea what the shark is like, a huge monster. good simple scary must watch if you want to not go in the water anymore. Besides the waters are dirty to swim in anyhow, depending on where you live.
Great movie classic with awesome music score. Terrifying and gripping Richard Dreyfuss did a great acting job.

reviews.review_title: Great stuff by the Great White
reviews.content: My top five films for sure.  I thoroughly enjoy this classic, mostly for the acting and relationships between Brody, Hooper, and Quint.  The final sequence involving these three and the shark always makes me sit on the edge of my seat.  Highly recommended!

I do not think I can contribute something new to what has already been written about JAWS. Simply put, it's a masterpiece. But what makes the movie so damn good? The answer to the question is: everything. It's a perfect monster movie and it's perfect because everything in JAWS interacts well with each other. The music, actors, script, Bruce the shark and, of course, Spielberg's direction makes this movie the timeless and ultimate model of how a monster film should feel and look.

This movie is my fave movie. It's a simple movie which delves into the characters but not too much so it keeps you entertained and intrigued. This movie is what has made me feel nervous whenever I swim in the sea. This movie started the summer blockbusters and began the whole craze of giant versions of animals craze e.g lake placid, anaconda, grizzly etc.

This movie really had an impact on my life! I use to live in Duxbury as a young child at the time my father decided to take me and my little brother to see. We heard the scary music and when the shark came around..my brother and I were under the seats of the movie patrons in front of us screaming and crying while my father laughed away thinking it was the greatest time in his life. Anyways...I use to love the water living in Duxbury Massachusetts...I still do! But I had to overcome the fear of the water thru the years and acquired a great interest in sharks. It made me more smart of our oceanic surroundings in New England. I've visited Martha's Vineyard for the JawsFest of 05 and was able to get up close to different points of interest of the movie. I'm 35 years old today....5 at the time of the release of the movie. I love the beach, the water and boating and fishing.This movie did change the way many people look at the ocean now and how much time they spend at the beaches actually "swimming". Jaws is one of the most successful and influential films of all time, and for good reason. Spielberg's first real success and a triumph in filmmaking. The cast is incredible and everyone in the film does an astounding job. They all have great chemistry and convey a real sense of humanity, also thanks to Spielberg's direction and script. The characters are all quite enjoyable and Chief Brody, Matt Hooper, and Quint are all unique characters with varying personalities creating a lot of funny banter and relationships that are thoroughly built throughout the film. Amity is also a very beautiful place and the environment and beach setting is quite nice paired with the fantastic camerawork. The cinematography is truly phenomenal and the pacing and editing create a lot of suspenseful and intense moments. The movie allows the viewer to watch as the camera pans from different characters and slowly moving back and forth, which allows the viewer to question who the Sharks next victim is. The tension building and sheer nerve racking moments are done perfectly and the Shark itself is a terrifying menace especially when It lurks under the water mostly out of sight and even out of the water the animatronic doesn't look terrible. The drama aspect of the also adds a lot and the perils of the characters are all conveyed quite early but are believable and relatable goals. The humanity and building up of the characters is when Spielberg is at his best however and there are a couple endearing moments. The final act is also a very adventurous and intense climax to an already amazingly well structured film. The writing is top notch perfection providing us with many classic lines and who could forget John Williams incredible score for the film. A truly memorable masterpiece that should be seen by everyone.

What can I say about a film that has become so famous in the world. At first it was mocked but over the years it has earned tremendous respect from anyone who saw it.The famous music that won an academy award truly summed up the tension and emotion that the film as a whole was trying to portray.The director worked very hard to make it work.They say it is the only film that "nearly broke him". Each character was unique,each scene carefully spaced out. The film has gone down as an all time classic and in my opinion it is truly worth seeing again from time to time.

reviews.review_title: "I still dont go in the Ocean"
reviews.content: Jaws is a fantastic flick. The casting was superb. The greatest compliment one can pay to an Actor is---that they truly became the character in question. Robert Shaw could not have been better. Roy Sheider and Richard Dryfuss were equally outstanding. They just dont make em' like this anymore.
